title.zh: 《秦始皇本紀》 Annals of Qin Shi Huang
title.raw: 《秦始皇本紀》 Annals of Qin Shi Huang

sentences.zh: 秦始皇帝者，秦莊襄王子也。

translations.text: The First Emperor of Qin was the son of King Zhuangxiang of Qin.

sentences.zh: 莊襄王為秦質子於趙，見呂不韋姬，悅而取之，生始皇。

translations.text: King Zhuangxiang had been a hostage of Qin in Zhao, where he saw Lü Buwei's concubine, was pleased with her, took her as his own, and she gave birth to the First Emperor.

sentences.zh: 以秦昭王四十八年正月生於邯鄲。

translations.text: He was born in the first month of the forty-eighth year of King Zhao of Qin at Handan.

sentences.zh: 及生，名為政，姓趙氏。

translations.text: When he was born, he was named Zheng and given the surname Zhao.

sentences.zh: 年十三歲，莊襄王死，政代立為秦王。

translations.text: At the age of thirteen, King Zhuangxiang died, and Zheng succeeded him as King of Qin.

sentences.zh: 當是之時，秦地已并巴、蜀、漢中，越宛有郢，置南郡矣；

translations.text: At that time, Qin's territory had already annexed Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, passed beyond Wan to possess Ying, and established Nan Commandery;

sentences.zh: 北收上郡以東，有河東、太原、上黨郡；

translations.text: to the north it had gathered Shangjun and eastward, possessing Hedong, Taiyuan, and Shangdang commanderies;

sentences.zh: 東至滎陽，滅二周，置三川郡。

translations.text: to the east it reached Xingyang, destroyed the Two Zhous, and established Sanchuan Commandery.

sentences.zh: 呂不韋為相，封十萬戶，號曰文信侯。

translations.text: Lü Buwei served as prime minister, was enfeoffed with one hundred thousand households, and titled Marquis Wenxin.

sentences.zh: 招致賓客游士，欲以并天下。

translations.text: He attracted guests and traveling scholars, intending to unify all under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 李斯為舍人。

translations.text: Li Si served as a retainer.

sentences.zh: 蒙驁、王齮、麃公等為將軍。

translations.text: Meng Ao, Wang He, and Biao Gong served as generals.

sentences.zh: 王年少，初即位，委國事大臣。

translations.text: The king was young and had just ascended the throne, so he entrusted state affairs to the great ministers.

The First Emperor of Qin was the son of King Zhuangxiang of Qin. King Zhuangxiang had been a hostage of Qin in Zhao, where he saw Lü Buwei's concubine, was pleased with her, took her as his own, and she gave birth to the First Emperor. He was born in the first month of the forty-eighth year of King Zhao of Qin at Handan. When he was born, he was named Zheng and given the surname Zhao. At the age of thirteen, King Zhuangxiang died, and Zheng succeeded him as King of Qin. At that time, Qin's territory had already annexed Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, passed beyond Wan to possess Ying, and established Nan Commandery; to the north it had gathered Shangjun and eastward, possessing Hedong, Taiyuan, and Shangdang commanderies; to the east it reached Xingyang, destroyed the Two Zhous, and established Sanchuan Commandery. Lü Buwei served as prime minister, was enfeoffed with one hundred thousand households, and titled Marquis Wenxin. He attracted guests and traveling scholars, intending to unify all under Heaven. Li Si served as a retainer. Meng Ao, Wang He, and Biao Gong served as generals. The king was young and had just ascended the throne, so he entrusted state affairs to the great ministers.

sentences.zh: 晉陽反，元年，將軍蒙驁擊定之。

translations.text: Jinyang rebelled; in the first year, General Meng Ao attacked and pacified it.

sentences.zh: 二年，麃公將卒攻卷，斬首三萬。

translations.text: In the second year, Biao Gong led troops to attack Juan, beheading thirty thousand.

sentences.zh: 三年，蒙驁攻韓，取十三城。

translations.text: In the third year, Meng Ao attacked Han and took thirteen cities.

sentences.zh: 王齮死。

translations.text: Wang He died.

sentences.zh: 十月，將軍蒙驁攻魏氏暢、有詭。

translations.text: In the tenth month, General Meng Ao attacked Chang and Yougui of Wei.

sentences.zh: 歲大饑。

translations.text: There was a great famine that year.

sentences.zh: 四年，拔暢、有詭。

translations.text: In the fourth year, they captured Chang and Yougui.

sentences.zh: 三月，軍罷。

translations.text: In the third month, the army disbanded.

sentences.zh: 秦質子歸自趙，趙太子出歸國。

translations.text: The Qin hostage returned from Zhao, and the Zhao crown prince went out and returned to his state.

sentences.zh: 十月庚寅，蝗蟲從東方來，蔽天。

translations.text: On the gengyin day of the tenth month, locusts came from the east and covered the sky.

sentences.zh: 天下疫。

translations.text: There was plague throughout the land.

sentences.zh: 百姓內粟千石，拜爵一級。

translations.text: Commoners who contributed a thousand shi of grain were granted one rank of nobility.

sentences.zh: 五年，將軍驁攻魏，定酸棗、燕、虛、長平、雍丘、山陽城，皆拔之，取二十城。

translations.text: In the fifth year, General Ao attacked Wei, pacified Suanzao, Yan, Xu, Changping, Yongqiu, and Shanyang, captured them all, and took twenty cities.

sentences.zh: 初置東郡。

translations.text: Dongjun Commandery was first established.

sentences.zh: 冬雷。

translations.text: There was thunder in winter.

sentences.zh: 六年，韓、魏、趙、衛、楚共擊秦，取壽陵。

translations.text: In the sixth year, Han, Wei, Zhao, Wei, and Chu jointly attacked Qin and took Shouling.

sentences.zh: 秦出兵，五國兵罷。

translations.text: Qin deployed troops, and the five states' armies disbanded.

sentences.zh: 拔衛，迫東郡，其君角率其支屬徙居野王，阻其山以保魏之河內。

translations.text: They captured Wei, pressed upon Dongjun; its lord Jiao led his kinsmen to relocate to Yewang, blocked off the mountains to protect Wei's Henei.

sentences.zh: 七年，彗星先出東方，見北方，五月見西方。

translations.text: In the seventh year, a comet first appeared in the east, was seen in the north, and in the fifth month was seen in the west.

sentences.zh: 將軍驁死。

translations.text: General Ao died.

sentences.zh: 以攻龍、孤、慶都，還兵攻汲。

translations.text: Troops attacked Long, Gu, and Qingdu, then returned to attack Ji.

sentences.zh: 彗星復見西方十六日。

translations.text: The comet appeared again in the west for sixteen days.

sentences.zh: 夏太后死。

translations.text: The Queen Dowager Xia died.

sentences.zh: 八年，王弟長安君成蟜將軍擊趙，反，死屯留，軍吏皆斬死，遷其民於臨洮。

translations.text: In the eighth year, the king's younger brother, Lord Chang'an Chengjiao, as general attacked Zhao, rebelled, and died at Tunliu; all military officers were beheaded and executed, and their people were relocated to Lintao.

sentences.zh: 將軍壁死，卒屯留、蒲鶴反，戮其尸。

translations.text: General Bi died; the troops of Tunliu and Puhe rebelled; his corpse was mutilated.

sentences.zh: 河魚大上，輕車重馬東就食。

translations.text: River fish swarmed upstream; light chariots and heavy horses went east to find food.

Jinyang rebelled; in the first year, General Meng Ao attacked and pacified it. In the second year, Biao Gong led troops to attack Juan, beheading thirty thousand. In the third year, Meng Ao attacked Han and took thirteen cities. Wang He died. In the tenth month, General Meng Ao attacked Chang and Yougui of Wei. There was a great famine that year. In the fourth year, they captured Chang and Yougui. In the third month, the army disbanded. The Qin hostage returned from Zhao, and the Zhao crown prince went out and returned to his state. On the gengyin day of the tenth month, locusts came from the east and covered the sky. There was plague throughout the land. Commoners who contributed a thousand shi of grain were granted one rank of nobility. In the fifth year, General Ao attacked Wei, pacified Suanzao, Yan, Xu, Changping, Yongqiu, and Shanyang, captured them all, and took twenty cities. Dongjun Commandery was first established. There was thunder in winter. In the sixth year, Han, Wei, Zhao, Wei, and Chu jointly attacked Qin and took Shouling. Qin deployed troops, and the five states' armies disbanded. They captured Wei, pressed upon Dongjun; its lord Jiao led his kinsmen to relocate to Yewang, blocked off the mountains to protect Wei's Henei. In the seventh year, a comet first appeared in the east, was seen in the north, and in the fifth month was seen in the west. General Ao died. Troops attacked Long, Gu, and Qingdu, then returned to attack Ji. The comet appeared again in the west for sixteen days. The Queen Dowager Xia died. In the eighth year, the king's younger brother, Lord Chang'an Chengjiao, as general attacked Zhao, rebelled, and died at Tunliu; all military officers were beheaded and executed, and their people were relocated to Lintao. General Bi died; the troops of Tunliu and Puhe rebelled; his corpse was mutilated. River fish swarmed upstream; light chariots and heavy horses went east to find food.

sentences.zh: 嫪毐封為長信侯。

translations.text: Lao Ai was enfeoffed as Marquis Changxin.

sentences.zh: 予之山陽地，令毐居之。

translations.text: He was given the lands of Shanyang, and Ai resided there.

sentences.zh: 宮室車馬衣服苑囿馳獵恣毐。

translations.text: Palaces, chariots, horses, clothing, parks, and hunting were all at Ai's disposal.

sentences.zh: 事無小大皆決於毐。

translations.text: Matters great and small were all decided by Ai.

sentences.zh: 又以河西太原郡更為毐國。

translations.text: Moreover, Hexi and Taiyuan commanderies were made into the State of Ai.

sentences.zh: 九年，彗星見，或竟天。

translations.text: In the ninth year, a comet appeared, some say across the entire sky.

sentences.zh: 攻魏垣、蒲陽。

translations.text: They attacked Wei's Yuan and Puyang.

sentences.zh: 四月，上宿雍。

translations.text: In the fourth month, the king stayed at Yong.

sentences.zh: 己酉，王冠，帶劍。

translations.text: On the jiyou day, the king was capped and wore his sword.

sentences.zh: 長信侯毐作亂而覺，矯王御璽及太后璽以發縣卒及衛卒、官騎、戎翟君公、舍人，將欲攻蘄年宮為亂。

translations.text: Marquis Changxin Ai created disorder and was discovered; he forged the king's seal and the Queen Mother's seal to mobilize county troops, palace guards, official cavalry, Rong and Di nobles, and retainers, intending to attack Qinian Palace and create chaos.

sentences.zh: 王知之，令相國昌平君、昌文君發卒攻毐。

translations.text: The king learned of this and ordered Prime Minister Lord Changping and Lord Changwen to mobilize troops to attack Ai.

sentences.zh: 戰咸陽，斬首數百，皆拜爵，及宦者皆在戰中，亦拜爵一級。

translations.text: They fought at Xianyang, beheaded several hundred; all were granted ranks of nobility, and eunuchs who participated in the battle were also granted one rank of nobility.

sentences.zh: 毐等敗走。

translations.text: Ai and his followers were defeated and fled.

sentences.zh: 即令國中：有生得毐，賜錢百萬；

translations.text: An immediate decree was issued throughout the state: whoever captures Ai alive will receive a million cash;

sentences.zh: 殺之，五十萬。

translations.text: whoever kills him, five hundred thousand.

sentences.zh: 盡得毐等。

translations.text: They captured all of Ai's followers.

sentences.zh: 衛尉竭、內史肆、佐弋竭、中大夫令齊等二十人皆梟首。

translations.text: Guard Commander Jie, Palace Attendant Si, Assistant Yijie, Palace Gentleman Commander Qi, and twenty others all had their heads displayed.

sentences.zh: 車裂以徇，滅其宗。

translations.text: They were torn apart by chariots as a warning, and their clans were exterminated.

sentences.zh: 及其舍人，輕者為鬼薪。

translations.text: As for his retainers, the lesser offenders were made to gather firewood for sacrifices.

sentences.zh: 及奪爵遷蜀四千餘家，家房陵。

translations.text: More than four thousand families who were stripped of rank and relocated to Shu were settled at Fangling.

sentences.zh: （四）［是］月寒凍，有死者。

translations.text: In that month there was severe cold and freezing; some died.

sentences.zh: 楊端和攻衍氏。

translations.text: Yang Duanhe attacked Yanshi.

sentences.zh: 彗星見西方，又見北方，從斗以南八十日。

translations.text: A comet appeared in the west and again in the north, extending south from the Dipper constellation for eighty days.

sentences.zh: 十年，相國呂不韋坐嫪毐免。

translations.text: In the tenth year, Prime Minister Lü Buwei was dismissed for his connection with Lao Ai.

sentences.zh: 桓齮為將軍。

translations.text: Huan He became general.

sentences.zh: 齊、趙來置酒。

translations.text: Qi and Zhao came to hold banquets.

sentences.zh: 齊人茅焦說秦王曰：「秦方以天下為事，而大王有遷母太后之名，恐諸侯聞之，由此倍秦也。」

translations.text: Mao Jiao of Qi persuaded the King of Qin, saying: "Qin is now concerned with all under Heaven, yet Your Majesty has the reputation of exiling his mother the Queen Mother; I fear the feudal lords will hear of this and thereby turn against Qin."

sentences.zh: 秦王乃迎太后於雍而入咸陽，復居甘泉宮。

translations.text: The King of Qin then welcomed the Queen Mother from Yong and brought her into Xianyang, and she again resided at Ganquan Palace.

Lao Ai was enfeoffed as Marquis Changxin. He was given the lands of Shanyang, and Ai resided there. Palaces, chariots, horses, clothing, parks, and hunting were all at Ai's disposal. Matters great and small were all decided by Ai. Moreover, Hexi and Taiyuan commanderies were made into the State of Ai. In the ninth year, a comet appeared, some say across the entire sky. They attacked Wei's Yuan and Puyang. In the fourth month, the king stayed at Yong. On the jiyou day, the king was capped and wore his sword. Marquis Changxin Ai created disorder and was discovered; he forged the king's seal and the Queen Mother's seal to mobilize county troops, palace guards, official cavalry, Rong and Di nobles, and retainers, intending to attack Qinian Palace and create chaos. The king learned of this and ordered Prime Minister Lord Changping and Lord Changwen to mobilize troops to attack Ai. They fought at Xianyang, beheaded several hundred; all were granted ranks of nobility, and eunuchs who participated in the battle were also granted one rank of nobility. Ai and his followers were defeated and fled. An immediate decree was issued throughout the state: whoever captures Ai alive will receive a million cash; whoever kills him, five hundred thousand. They captured all of Ai's followers. Guard Commander Jie, Palace Attendant Si, Assistant Yijie, Palace Gentleman Commander Qi, and twenty others all had their heads displayed. They were torn apart by chariots as a warning, and their clans were exterminated. As for his retainers, the lesser offenders were made to gather firewood for sacrifices. More than four thousand families who were stripped of rank and relocated to Shu were settled at Fangling. In that month there was severe cold and freezing; some died. Yang Duanhe attacked Yanshi. A comet appeared in the west and again in the north, extending south from the Dipper constellation for eighty days. In the tenth year, Prime Minister Lü Buwei was dismissed for his connection with Lao Ai. Huan He became general. Qi and Zhao came to hold banquets. Mao Jiao of Qi persuaded the King of Qin, saying: "Qin is now concerned with all under Heaven, yet Your Majesty has the reputation of exiling his mother the Queen Mother; I fear the feudal lords will hear of this and thereby turn against Qin." The King of Qin then welcomed the Queen Mother from Yong and brought her into Xianyang, and she again resided at Ganquan Palace.

sentences.zh: 大索，逐客，李斯上書說，乃止逐客令。

translations.text: There was a great search and expulsion of foreign guests; Li Si submitted a memorial in persuasion, and the expulsion order was then halted.

sentences.zh: 李斯因說秦王，請先取韓以恐他國，於是使斯下韓。

translations.text: Li Si then persuaded the King of Qin to first take Han to intimidate the other states, so he sent Si to subdue Han.

sentences.zh: 韓王患之。

translations.text: The King of Han was troubled by this.

sentences.zh: 與韓非謀弱秦。

translations.text: He plotted with Han Fei to weaken Qin.

sentences.zh: 大梁人尉繚來，說秦王曰：「以秦之彊，諸侯譬如郡縣之君，臣但恐諸侯合從，翕而出不意，此乃智伯、夫差、湣王之所以亡也。

translations.text: Wei Liao from Daliang came and persuaded the King of Qin, saying: "With Qin's strength, the feudal lords are like commandery and county lords; I only fear the feudal lords will form a vertical alliance and suddenly act unexpectedly; this is how Zhi Bo, Fuchai, and King Min came to perish.

sentences.zh: 願大王毋愛財物，賂其豪臣，以亂其謀，不過亡三十萬金，則諸侯可盡。」

translations.text: I hope Your Majesty will not begrudge wealth and treasures; bribe their powerful ministers to disrupt their plans; spending no more than three hundred thousand gold, all the feudal lords can be eliminated."

sentences.zh: 秦王從其計，見尉繚亢禮，衣服食飲與繚同。

translations.text: The King of Qin followed his plan, treated Wei Liao with the highest courtesy, and shared clothing, food, and drink with Liao.

sentences.zh: 繚曰：「秦王為人，蜂準，長目，摯鳥膺，豺聲，少恩而虎狼心，居約易出人下，得志亦輕食人。

translations.text: Liao said: "The King of Qin is a person with a wasp-like nose, elongated eyes, a bird of prey's chest, a jackal's voice, little kindness and a tiger-wolf heart; when in difficulty he easily humbles himself before others, but when successful he easily devours people.

sentences.zh: 我布衣，然見我常身自下我。

translations.text: I am a commoner, yet when he sees me he personally humbles himself before me.

sentences.zh: 誠使秦王得志於天下，天下皆為虜矣。

translations.text: If truly the King of Qin achieves his ambitions over all under Heaven, all under Heaven will become slaves.

sentences.zh: 不可與久游。」

translations.text: One cannot associate with him for long."

sentences.zh: 乃亡去。

translations.text: He then fled.

sentences.zh: 秦王覺，固止，以為秦國尉，卒用其計策。

translations.text: The King of Qin realized this, firmly detained him, made him National Commander of Qin, and in the end used his strategies.

sentences.zh: 而李斯用事。

translations.text: And Li Si handled affairs.

There was a great search and expulsion of foreign guests; Li Si submitted a memorial in persuasion, and the expulsion order was then halted. Li Si then persuaded the King of Qin to first take Han to intimidate the other states, so he sent Si to subdue Han. The King of Han was troubled by this. He plotted with Han Fei to weaken Qin. Wei Liao from Daliang came and persuaded the King of Qin, saying: "With Qin's strength, the feudal lords are like commandery and county lords; I only fear the feudal lords will form a vertical alliance and suddenly act unexpectedly; this is how Zhi Bo, Fuchai, and King Min came to perish. I hope Your Majesty will not begrudge wealth and treasures; bribe their powerful ministers to disrupt their plans; spending no more than three hundred thousand gold, all the feudal lords can be eliminated." The King of Qin followed his plan, treated Wei Liao with the highest courtesy, and shared clothing, food, and drink with Liao. Liao said: "The King of Qin is a person with a wasp-like nose, elongated eyes, a bird of prey's chest, a jackal's voice, little kindness and a tiger-wolf heart; when in difficulty he easily humbles himself before others, but when successful he easily devours people. I am a commoner, yet when he sees me he personally humbles himself before me. If truly the King of Qin achieves his ambitions over all under Heaven, all under Heaven will become slaves. One cannot associate with him for long." He then fled. The King of Qin realized this, firmly detained him, made him National Commander of Qin, and in the end used his strategies. And Li Si handled affairs.

sentences.zh: 十一年，王翦、桓齮、楊端和攻鄴，取九城。

translations.text: In the eleventh year, Wang Jian, Huan He, and Yang Duanhe attacked Ye and took nine cities.

sentences.zh: 王翦攻閼與、橑楊，皆并為一軍。

translations.text: Wang Jian attacked Eyu and Laoyang, all combining into one army.

sentences.zh: 翦將十八日，軍歸斗食以下，什推二人從軍取鄴安陽，桓齮將。

translations.text: Jian commanded for eighteen days; the army returned; from dou-rank officials downward, two out of ten followed the army to take Ye and Anyang; Huan He commanded.

sentences.zh: 十二年，文信侯不韋死，竊葬。

translations.text: In the twelfth year, Marquis Wenxin Buwei died and was buried secretly.

sentences.zh: 其舍人臨者，晉人也逐出之；

translations.text: Among his retainers, those who attended the funeral and were from Jin were expelled;

sentences.zh: 秦人六百石以上奪爵，遷；

translations.text: Qin people of six hundred shi rank and above were stripped of rank and exiled;

sentences.zh: 五百石以下不臨，遷，勿奪爵。

translations.text: those of five hundred shi and below who did not attend the funeral were exiled but not stripped of rank.

sentences.zh: 自今以來，操國事不道如嫪毐、不韋者籍其門，視此。

translations.text: From now on, those who handle state affairs improperly like Lao Ai and Buwei will have their households registered; observe this.

sentences.zh: 秋，復嫪毐舍人遷蜀者。

translations.text: In autumn, the retainers of Lao Ai who had been exiled to Shu were pardoned.

sentences.zh: 當是之時，天下大旱，六月至八月乃雨。

translations.text: At that time, there was a great drought throughout the land; from the sixth to the eighth month it finally rained.

In the eleventh year, Wang Jian, Huan He, and Yang Duanhe attacked Ye and took nine cities. Wang Jian attacked Eyu and Laoyang, all combining into one army. Jian commanded for eighteen days; the army returned; from dou-rank officials downward, two out of ten followed the army to take Ye and Anyang; Huan He commanded. In the twelfth year, Marquis Wenxin Buwei died and was buried secretly. Among his retainers, those who attended the funeral and were from Jin were expelled; Qin people of six hundred shi rank and above were stripped of rank and exiled; those of five hundred shi and below who did not attend the funeral were exiled but not stripped of rank. From now on, those who handle state affairs improperly like Lao Ai and Buwei will have their households registered; observe this. In autumn, the retainers of Lao Ai who had been exiled to Shu were pardoned. At that time, there was a great drought throughout the land; from the sixth to the eighth month it finally rained.

sentences.zh: 十三年，桓齮攻趙平陽，殺趙將扈輒，斬首十萬。

translations.text: In the thirteenth year, Huan He attacked Pingyang of Zhao, killed Zhao general Hu Zhe, and beheaded one hundred thousand.

sentences.zh: 王之河南。

translations.text: The king went to Henan.

sentences.zh: 正月，彗星見東方。

translations.text: In the first month, a comet appeared in the east.

sentences.zh: 十月，桓齮攻趙。

translations.text: In the tenth month, Huan He attacked Zhao.

sentences.zh: 十四年，攻趙軍於平陽，取宜安，破之，殺其將軍。

translations.text: In the fourteenth year, they attacked Zhao's army at Pingyang, took Yi'an, defeated it, and killed its general.

sentences.zh: 桓齮定平陽、武城。

translations.text: Huan He pacified Pingyang and Wucheng.

sentences.zh: 韓非使秦，秦用李斯謀，留非，非死雲陽。

translations.text: Han Fei came as envoy to Qin; Qin used Li Si's plot, detained Fei, and Fei died at Yunyang.

sentences.zh: 韓王請為臣。

translations.text: The King of Han requested to become a vassal.

In the thirteenth year, Huan He attacked Pingyang of Zhao, killed Zhao general Hu Zhe, and beheaded one hundred thousand. The king went to Henan. In the first month, a comet appeared in the east. In the tenth month, Huan He attacked Zhao. In the fourteenth year, they attacked Zhao's army at Pingyang, took Yi'an, defeated it, and killed its general. Huan He pacified Pingyang and Wucheng. translations.text: The King of Qi used Hou Sheng's plan, cut off Qin envoys, and intended to create disorder; our officers and troops punished them, captured their king, and pacified Qi's territory.

sentences.zh: 寡人以眇眇之身，興兵誅暴亂，賴宗廟之靈，六王咸伏其辜，天下大定。

translations.text: I, with my humble person, raised troops to punish violent chaos, and relying on the spirits of the ancestral temples, the six kings all received their due punishment, and all under Heaven is greatly pacified.

sentences.zh: 今名號不更，無以稱成功，傳後世。

translations.text: Prime Minister Wan, Grand Censor Jie, Commandant of Justice Si and others all said: "In ancient times the Five Emperors' territory was a thousand li square; beyond it were the hou and yi service zones where feudal lords sometimes came to court and sometimes did not, and the Son of Heaven could not control them.

sentences.zh: 今陛下興義兵，誅殘賊，平定天下，海內為郡縣，法令由一統，自上古以來未嘗有，五帝所不及。

translations.text: Now Your Majesty has raised righteous troops, punished cruel rebels, pacified all under Heaven; all within the seas has become commanderies and counties, laws and decrees are unified under one authority; from high antiquity this has never occurred, beyond what the Five Emperors achieved.

sentences.zh: 臣等謹與博士議曰：『古有天皇，有地皇，有泰皇，泰皇最貴。』

translations.text: We your ministers carefully deliberated with the scholars and said: 'In ancient times there was the Tianhuang, the Dihuang, and the Taihuang; the Taihuang was most noble.'

sentences.zh: 臣等昧死上尊號，王為『泰皇』。

translations.text: We your ministers at risk of death present the honored title: that the king be called 'Taihuang.'

sentences.zh: 命為『制』，令為『詔』，天子自稱曰『朕』。」

translations.text: Commands shall be called 'zhi,' decrees shall be called 'zhao,' and the Son of Heaven shall refer to himself as 'zhen.'"

sentences.zh: 王曰：「去『泰』，著『皇』，采上古『帝』位號，號曰『皇帝』。

sentences.zh: 他如議。」

translations.text: For other matters, proceed as discussed."

sentences.zh: 制曰：「朕聞太古有號毋謚，中古有號，死而以行為謐。

translations.text: The decree said: "I have heard that in high antiquity there were titles but no posthumous names; in middle antiquity there were titles, and upon death posthumous names were given based on their conduct.

sentences.zh: 如此，則子議父，臣議君也，甚無謂，朕弗取焉。

translations.text: If this is so, then sons judge fathers and ministers judge lords, which is utterly meaningless; I will not adopt this.

sentences.zh: 自今已來，除謚法。

translations.text: From now on, abolish the system of posthumous names.

sentences.zh: 朕為始皇帝。

translations.text: I am the First Emperor.

sentences.zh: 後世以計數，二世三世至于萬世，傳之無窮。」

When the King of Qin first unified all under Heaven, he ordered the prime minister and Imperial Secretary: "In the past, the King of Han surrendered territory and presented his seals, requesting to be a vassal state, but then broke the agreement and joined with Zhao and Wei in a vertical alliance to rebel against Qin; therefore we raised troops to punish him and captured their king. I considered this good, hoping to end military campaigns. The King of Zhao sent his prime minister Li Mu to make a treaty, so we returned their hostage. But then they broke the treaty and took back our Taiyuan; therefore we raised troops to punish them and captured their king. Prince Jia of Zhao then proclaimed himself King of Dai, so we raised troops to attack and destroy him. The King of Wei first agreed to submit and enter Qin, but then plotted with Han and Zhao to attack Qin; our officers and troops punished them and defeated them. The King of Jing offered territory west of Qingyang, but then broke the agreement and attacked our Nan Commandery; therefore we mobilized troops to punish him, captured their king, and pacified their lands of Jing. The King of Yan was confused and chaotic; his crown prince Dan then secretly ordered Jing Ke to commit treachery; our officers and troops punished them and destroyed their state. The King of Qi used Hou Sheng's plan, cut off Qin envoys, and intended to create disorder; our officers and troops punished them, captured their king, and pacified Qi's territory. I, with my humble person, raised troops to punish violent chaos, and relying on the spirits of the ancestral temples, the six kings all received their due punishment, and all under Heaven is greatly pacified. Now if the title and name are not changed, there will be no way to proclaim the accomplishment and transmit it to later generations. Discuss the imperial title." Prime Minister Wan, Grand Censor Jie, Commandant of Justice Si and others all said: "In ancient times the Five Emperors' territory was a thousand li square; beyond it were the hou and yi service zones where feudal lords sometimes came to court and sometimes did not, and the Son of Heaven could not control them. Now Your Majesty has raised righteous troops, punished cruel rebels, pacified all under Heaven; all within the seas has become commanderies and counties, laws and decrees are unified under one authority; from high antiquity this has never occurred, beyond what the Five Emperors achieved. We your ministers carefully deliberated with the scholars and said: 'In ancient times there was the Tianhuang, the Dihuang, and the Taihuang; the Taihuang was most noble.' We your ministers at risk of death present the honored title: that the king be called 'Taihuang.' Commands shall be called 'zhi,' decrees shall be called 'zhao,' and the Son of Heaven shall refer to himself as 'zhen.'" The king said: "Remove 'Tai,' retain 'Huang,' and adopt the ancient title 'Di,' to be called 'Huangdi' (Emperor). For other matters, proceed as discussed." The decree said: "Approved." He posthumously honored King Zhuangxiang as the Grand Supreme Sovereign. The decree said: "I have heard that in high antiquity there were titles but no posthumous names; in middle antiquity there were titles, and upon death posthumous names were given based on their conduct. If this is so, then sons judge fathers and ministers judge lords, which is utterly meaningless; I will not adopt this. From now on, abolish the system of posthumous names. I am the First Emperor. Later generations shall be counted numerically: Second Generation, Third Generation, up to ten thousand generations, transmitted without end."

sentences.zh: 始皇推終始五德之傳，以為周得火德，秦代周德，從所不勝。

translations.text: The First Emperor, reasoning through the transmission of the Five Virtues from beginning to end, considered that Zhou possessed the virtue of Fire, and since Qin replaced Zhou's virtue, it followed what it did not conquer.

sentences.zh: 方今水德之始，改年始，朝賀皆自十月朔。

translations.text: Now at the beginning of the Water virtue, the year's beginning was changed; court audiences and congratulations all began from the first day of the tenth month.

translations.text: The Yellow River was renamed De River, marking the beginning of the Water virtue.

translations.text: Firm, resolute, stern, and profound, all matters were decided by law, severe and without benevolence, kindness, harmony, or righteousness, only then matching the number of the Five Virtues.

sentences.zh: 丞相綰等言：「諸侯初破，燕、齊、荊地遠，不為置王，毋以填之。

translations.text: Commandant of Justice Li Si argued: "The sons, younger brothers, and clansmen enfeoffed by Kings Wen and Wu of Zhou were very numerous, but later when relations became distant, they attacked each other like enemies; feudal lords mutually attacked and killed each other, and the Son of Heaven of Zhou could not prohibit or stop it.

translations.text: Now all within the seas, relying on Your Majesty's divine power, is unified as commanderies and counties; princes and meritorious officials are abundantly rewarded with tax revenues; this is very easy to control.

sentences.zh: 天下無異意，則安寧之術也。

translations.text: When all under Heaven has no divergent intentions, this is the technique of peace and tranquility.

sentences.zh: 置諸侯不便。」

translations.text: Establishing feudal lords is not expedient."

translations.text: The First Emperor said: "All under Heaven suffered bitterly from incessant warfare because of the existence of lords and kings.

sentences.zh: 賴宗廟，天下初定，又復立國，是樹兵也，而求其寧息，豈不難哉！

translations.text: Relying on the ancestral temples, all under Heaven has just been pacified; if we again establish states, this is planting the seeds of war; to seek peace and tranquility would be truly difficult!

sentences.zh: 廷尉議是。」

Commandant of Justice Li Si argued: "The sons, younger brothers, and clansmen enfeoffed by Kings Wen and Wu of Zhou were very numerous, but later when relations became distant, they attacked each other like enemies; feudal lords mutually attacked and killed each other, and the Son of Heaven of Zhou could not prohibit or stop it. Now all within the seas, relying on Your Majesty's divine power, is unified as commanderies and counties; princes and meritorious officials are abundantly rewarded with tax revenues; this is very easy to control. When all under Heaven has no divergent intentions, this is the technique of peace and tranquility. Establishing feudal lords is not expedient." The First Emperor said: "All under Heaven suffered bitterly from incessant warfare because of the existence of lords and kings. Relying on the ancestral temples, all under Heaven has just been pacified; if we again establish states, this is planting the seeds of war; to seek peace and tranquility would be truly difficult! The Commandant of Justice's argument is correct."

In the thirty-sixth year, Mars remained in the Heart constellation. A meteorite fell in Dongjun; when it reached the ground and became stone, some among the black-headed people carved on the stone: 'The First Emperor will die and the land will be divided.' When the First Emperor heard of this, he sent censors to pursue and question them; none confessed, so he seized all the residents near the stone and executed them, then burned and melted the stone. The First Emperor was displeased; he had scholars compose poems about immortals and true persons, and as he traveled throughout the land, had musicians sing and play them. In autumn, an envoy from east of the passes at night passed through Huayin on the Pingshu road; someone holding a jade disk blocked the envoy and said: "Give this to the Lord of Haochi for me." He then said: "This year the ancestral dragon will die." The envoy asked why, but the person suddenly disappeared, leaving the jade disk. The envoy presented the jade disk and reported everything he had heard. The First Emperor was silent for a long while, then said: "Mountain spirits can only know one year's events." Withdrawing he said: "The ancestral dragon refers to the ancestor of men." He had the imperial treasury examine the jade disk; it was the disk that had been cast into the river when crossing the Yangtze in the twenty-eighth year. Thereupon the First Emperor divined; the divination yielded that traveling and relocating were auspicious. He relocated thirty thousand households north of the Yellow River to Yuzhong. He granted one rank of nobility.

translations.text: His youngest son Huhai, longing to go, requested to accompany him, and the emperor permitted it.

translations.text: He ascended Kuaiji, made sacrifices to the Great Yu, gazed upon the Southern Sea, and erected stone inscriptions praising Qin's virtue.

sentences.zh: 皇帝休烈，平一宇內，德惠修長。

translations.text: The Emperor's splendid achievements unified all within the universe; his virtue and beneficence are cultivated and enduring.

sentences.zh: 三十有七年，親巡天下，周覽遠方。

translations.text: In the thirty-seventh year, he personally toured all under Heaven, comprehensively surveying distant regions.

sentences.zh: 遂登會稽，宣省習俗，黔首齋莊。

translations.text: He then ascended Kuaiji, proclaimed and inspected customs; the black-headed people were reverent and solemn.

sentences.zh: 群臣誦功，本原事跡，追首高明。

translations.text: The assembled ministers recited his achievements, traced the origins of events, and pursued his lofty brilliance.

sentences.zh: 秦聖臨國，始定刑名，顯陳舊章。

translations.text: The Qin sage governed the state, first established criminal names, and clearly displayed ancient regulations.

sentences.zh: 初平法式，審別職任，以立恒常。

translations.text: Initially he leveled laws and regulations, carefully distinguished official duties, to establish permanent standards.

sentences.zh: 六王專倍，貪戾傲猛，率眾自彊。

translations.text: The six kings were monopolistic and treacherous, greedy, cruel, arrogant, and fierce, leading masses to strengthen themselves.

sentences.zh: 暴虐恣行，負力而驕，數動甲兵。

translations.text: Violent and tyrannical, they acted with abandon, relying on force they were arrogant, frequently mobilizing troops.

sentences.zh: 陰通閒使，以事合從，行為辟方。

translations.text: Secretly they sent covert envoys, using affairs to form vertical alliances, acting in devious ways.

sentences.zh: 內飾詐謀，外來侵邊，遂起禍殃。

translations.text: Internally they adorned themselves with deceitful plots, externally they came to invade borders, thereby bringing about disaster.

sentences.zh: 義威誅之，殄熄暴悖，亂賊滅亡。

translations.text: With righteous authority he executed them, completely extinguished violent rebels; chaotic traitors were destroyed.

sentences.zh: 聖德廣密，六合之中，被澤無疆。

translations.text: His sage virtue was broadly profound; within the six directions, his beneficence spread without limit.

sentences.zh: 皇帝并宇，兼聽萬事，遠近畢清。

translations.text: The Emperor unified the universe, comprehensively attended to all affairs; far and near all were thoroughly purified.

sentences.zh: 運理群物，考驗事實，各載其名。

translations.text: He adorned, examined, and proclaimed righteousness: having a son yet marrying another, betraying the deceased, being unchaste.

sentences.zh: 防隔內外，禁止淫泆，男女絜誠。

translations.text: Separating inside and outside, prohibiting and stopping licentiousness; men and women were pure and sincere.

sentences.zh: 夫為寄豭，殺之無罪，男秉義程。

translations.text: If a husband was a stud boar, killing him incurred no punishment; males held to the righteous standard.

sentences.zh: 妻為逃嫁，子不得母，咸化廉清。

translations.text: If a wife eloped, the son could not obtain his mother; all were transformed to be honest and pure.

sentences.zh: 大治濯俗，天下承風，蒙被休經。

translations.text: Greatly governing and purifying customs, all under Heaven received the wind of transformation, bathed in his splendid teachings.

sentences.zh: 皆遵度軌，和安敦勉，莫不順令。

translations.text: All followed the standards and regulations, harmonious, peaceful, sincere, and diligent; none did not obey commands.

sentences.zh: 黔首修絜，人樂同則，嘉保太平。

translations.text: The black-headed people cultivated purity; people delighted in common standards, joyfully preserving great peace.

sentences.zh: 後敬奉法，常治無極，輿舟不傾。

The Emperor's splendid achievements unified all within the universe; his virtue and beneficence are cultivated and enduring. In the thirty-seventh year, he personally toured all under Heaven, comprehensively surveying distant regions. He then ascended Kuaiji, proclaimed and inspected customs; the black-headed people were reverent and solemn. The assembled ministers recited his achievements, traced the origins of events, and pursued his lofty brilliance. The Qin sage governed the state, first established criminal names, and clearly displayed ancient regulations. Initially he leveled laws and regulations, carefully distinguished official duties, to establish permanent standards. The six kings were monopolistic and treacherous, greedy, cruel, arrogant, and fierce, leading masses to strengthen themselves. Violent and tyrannical, they acted with abandon, relying on force they were arrogant, frequently mobilizing troops. Secretly they sent covert envoys, using affairs to form vertical alliances, acting in devious ways. Internally they adorned themselves with deceitful plots, externally they came to invade borders, thereby bringing about disaster. With righteous authority he executed them, completely extinguished violent rebels; chaotic traitors were destroyed. His sage virtue was broadly profound; within the six directions, his beneficence spread without limit. The Emperor unified the universe, comprehensively attended to all affairs; far and near all were thoroughly purified. Managing and governing the multitude of things, examining and verifying actual affairs, each bearing its name. Noble and base both communicated, good and bad were displayed before him; there was nothing hidden. Separating inside and outside, prohibiting and stopping licentiousness; men and women were pure and sincere. The attending ministers recite his achievements and request to carve this stone, gloriously displaying the splendid inscription.

sentences.zh: 還過吳，從江乘渡。

translations.text: Returning, he passed through Wu and crossed from Jiangcheng.

sentences.zh: 并海上，北至瑯邪。

translations.text: He went up along the sea and north to Langye.

sentences.zh: 方士徐市等入海求神藥，數歲不得，費多，恐譴，乃詐曰：「蓬萊藥可得，然常為大鮫魚所苦，故不得至，願請善射與俱，見則以連弩射之。」

translations.text: The practitioner Xu Shi and others entered the sea seeking divine medicine; after several years without obtaining it and having spent much, fearing punishment, they fabricated a story: "The Penglai medicine can be obtained, but we are constantly troubled by large sharks, so we cannot reach it; we request good archers to accompany us; when we see them we will shoot them with multiple crossbows."

sentences.zh: 始皇夢與海神戰，如人狀。

translations.text: The First Emperor dreamed of battling a sea god in human form.

sentences.zh: 問占夢，博士曰：「水神不可見，以大魚蛟龍為候。

translations.text: He inquired about dream interpretation; the scholars said: "Water gods cannot be seen; they use large fish and flood dragons as their manifestations.

sentences.zh: 今上禱祠備謹，而有此惡神，當除去，而善神可致。」

translations.text: Now the superior's prayers and offerings are thorough and respectful, yet there is this evil god; it should be removed, and good gods can be attracted."

sentences.zh: 乃令入海者齎捕巨魚具，而自以連弩候大魚出射之。

translations.text: He then ordered those entering the sea to carry equipment for catching giant fish, and he himself waited with multiple crossbows for large fish to appear and shot them.

sentences.zh: 自瑯邪北至榮成山，弗見。

translations.text: From Langye north to Rongcheng Mountain, he saw none.

sentences.zh: 至之罘，見巨魚，射殺一魚。

translations.text: At Zhifu, he saw a giant fish and shot and killed one fish.

sentences.zh: 遂并海西。

translations.text: He then went west along the sea.

Returning, he passed through Wu and crossed from Jiangcheng. He went up along the sea and north to Langye. The practitioner Xu Shi and others entered the sea seeking divine medicine; after several years without obtaining it and having spent much, fearing punishment, they fabricated a story: "The Penglai medicine can be obtained, but we are constantly troubled by large sharks, so we cannot reach it; we request good archers to accompany us; when we see them we will shoot them with multiple crossbows." The First Emperor dreamed of battling a sea god in human form. He inquired about dream interpretation; the scholars said: "Water gods cannot be seen; they use large fish and flood dragons as their manifestations. Now the superior's prayers and offerings are thorough and respectful, yet there is this evil god; it should be removed, and good gods can be attracted." He then ordered those entering the sea to carry equipment for catching giant fish, and he himself waited with multiple crossbows for large fish to appear and shot them. From Langye north to Rongcheng Mountain, he saw none. At Zhifu, he saw a giant fish and shot and killed one fish. He then went west along the sea.

sentences.zh: 至平原津而病。

translations.text: At Pingyuan ford he fell ill.

sentences.zh: 始皇惡言死，群臣莫敢言死事。

translations.text: The First Emperor hated speaking of death, and none of the assembled ministers dared speak of death matters.

sentences.zh: 上病益甚，乃為璽書賜公子扶蘇曰：「與喪會咸陽而葬。」

translations.text: The emperor's illness grew worse, so he composed a sealed edict to Prince Fusu saying: "Attend the funeral at Xianyang and perform the burial."

sentences.zh: 書已封，在中車府令趙高行符璽事所，未授使者。

translations.text: The document was already sealed and was with Director of the Imperial Carriage Zhao Gao who handled seal matters, but had not yet been given to the envoy.

sentences.zh: 七月丙寅，始皇崩於沙丘平臺。

translations.text: On the bingyin day of the seventh month, the First Emperor died at the Pingtai of Shaqiu.

sentences.zh: 丞相斯為上崩在外，恐諸公子及天下有變，乃祕之，不發喪。

translations.text: Prime Minister Si, because the emperor died away from the capital, feared that the princes and all under Heaven would revolt, so he kept it secret and did not announce the death.

sentences.zh: 棺載轀涼車中，故幸宦者參乘，所至上食。

translations.text: The coffin was placed in a warm-cool carriage; his formerly favored eunuchs attended; wherever they arrived food was presented to the emperor.

sentences.zh: 百官奏事如故，宦者輒從轀涼車中可其奏事。

translations.text: The hundred officials submitted memorials as usual, and eunuchs from within the warm-cool carriage would approve the submitted memorials.

sentences.zh: 獨子胡亥、趙高及所幸宦者五六人知上死。

translations.text: Only Prince Huhai, Zhao Gao, and five or six favored eunuchs knew the emperor had died.

sentences.zh: 趙高故嘗教胡亥書及獄律令法事，胡亥私幸之。

translations.text: Zhao Gao had formerly taught Huhai writing and prison law matters, and Huhai privately favored him.

sentences.zh: 高乃與公子胡亥、丞相斯陰謀破去始皇所封書賜公子扶蘇者，而更詐為丞相斯受始皇遺詔沙丘，立子胡亥為太子。

translations.text: Gao then secretly plotted with Prince Huhai and Prime Minister Si to destroy the sealed document the First Emperor had given to Prince Fusu, and instead forged a decree saying Prime Minister Si had received the First Emperor's last testament at Shaqiu to install Prince Huhai as crown prince.

sentences.zh: 更為書賜公子扶蘇、蒙恬，數以罪，（其）賜死。

translations.text: They forged another document to be given to Prince Fusu and Meng Tian, listing their crimes and bestowing death upon them.

sentences.zh: 語具在李斯傳中。

translations.text: The full account is in the biography of Li Si.

sentences.zh: 行，遂從井陘抵九原。

translations.text: They traveled on, passing through Jingxing to reach Jiuyuan.

sentences.zh: 會暑，上轀車臭，乃詔從官令車載一石鮑魚，以亂其臭。

translations.text: With the heat of summer, the warm carriage with the corpse stank, so they decreed that attending officials should have each carriage carry one shi of salted fish to mask the smell.

At Pingyuan ford he fell ill. The First Emperor hated speaking of death, and none of the assembled ministers dared speak of death matters. The emperor's illness grew worse, so he composed a sealed edict to Prince Fusu saying: "Attend the funeral at Xianyang and perform the burial." The document was already sealed and was with Director of the Imperial Carriage Zhao Gao who handled seal matters, but had not yet been given to the envoy. On the bingyin day of the seventh month, the First Emperor died at the Pingtai of Shaqiu. Prime Minister Si, because the emperor died away from the capital, feared that the princes and all under Heaven would revolt, so he kept it secret and did not announce the death. The coffin was placed in a warm-cool carriage; his formerly favored eunuchs attended; wherever they arrived food was presented to the emperor. The hundred officials submitted memorials as usual, and eunuchs from within the warm-cool carriage would approve the submitted memorials. Only Prince Huhai, Zhao Gao, and five or six favored eunuchs knew the emperor had died. Zhao Gao had formerly taught Huhai writing and prison law matters, and Huhai privately favored him. Gao then secretly plotted with Prince Huhai and Prime Minister Si to destroy the sealed document the First Emperor had given to Prince Fusu, and instead forged a decree saying Prime Minister Si had received the First Emperor's last testament at Shaqiu to install Prince Huhai as crown prince. They forged another document to be given to Prince Fusu and Meng Tian, listing their crimes and bestowing death upon them. The full account is in the biography of Li Si. They traveled on, passing through Jingxing to reach Jiuyuan. With the heat of summer, the warm carriage with the corpse stank, so they decreed that attending officials should have each carriage carry one shi of salted fish to mask the smell.

sentences.zh: 行從直道至咸陽，發喪。

translations.text: They traveled via the straight road to Xianyang and announced the death.

sentences.zh: 太子胡亥襲位，為二世皇帝。

translations.text: Crown Prince Huhai succeeded to the throne as the Second Generation Emperor.

sentences.zh: 九月，葬始皇酈山。

translations.text: In the ninth month, the First Emperor was buried at Lishan.

sentences.zh: 始皇初即位，穿治酈山，及并天下，天下徒送詣七十餘萬人，穿三泉，下銅而致槨，宮觀百官奇器珍怪徙臧滿之。

translations.text: When the First Emperor first ascended the throne, he began excavating and constructing at Lishan; when he unified all under Heaven, convicts sent from throughout the land numbered over seven hundred thousand; they dug through three underground springs, poured copper and placed the coffin chamber, and filled it with palaces, officials, rare implements, and precious curiosities relocated there.

sentences.zh: 令匠作機弩矢，有所穿近者輒射之。

translations.text: He ordered craftsmen to make mechanical crossbows and arrows; if anyone came near to penetrate, they would immediately shoot them.

sentences.zh: 以水銀為百川江河大海，機相灌輸，上具天文，下具地理。

translations.text: With mercury they made the hundred rivers, the Yangtze and Yellow rivers, and the great sea, with mechanisms that made them flow into each other; above they depicted the heavenly bodies, below they depicted the geography.

sentences.zh: 以人魚膏為燭，度不滅者久之。

translations.text: Using mermaid oil as candles, they calculated they would not be extinguished for a long time.

sentences.zh: 二世曰：「先帝後宮非有子者，出焉不宜。」

translations.text: The Second Emperor said: "The former emperor's rear palace—those who had no sons should not go out; this would not be proper."

sentences.zh: 皆令從死，死者甚眾。

translations.text: He ordered them all to follow him in death; those who died were very numerous.

sentences.zh: 葬既已下，或言工匠為機，臧皆知之，臧重即泄。

translations.text: After the burial had been completed, someone said that the craftsmen who made the mechanisms all knew what was stored, and if what was stored became known it would be revealed.

sentences.zh: 大事畢，已臧，閉中羨，下外羨門，盡閉工匠臧者，無復出者。

translations.text: When the great affair was completed and storage finished, they closed the middle passage door and lowered the outer passage door, completely sealing in all the craftsmen and those who stored treasures; none ever came out again.

sentences.zh: 樹草木以象山。

translations.text: Trees and grass were planted to simulate mountains.

sentences.zh: 二世皇帝元年，年二十一。

translations.text: In the first year of the Second Generation Emperor, he was twenty-one years old.

sentences.zh: 趙高為郎中令，任用事。

translations.text: Zhao Gao served as Palace Attendant Commander and handled affairs.

sentences.zh: 二世下詔，增始皇寢廟犧牲及山川百祀之禮。

translations.text: The Second Emperor issued a decree increasing sacrificial animals for the First Emperor's mortuary temple and the rituals for mountains, rivers, and the hundred spirits.

sentences.zh: 令群臣議尊始皇廟。

translations.text: He ordered the assembled ministers to discuss honoring the First Emperor's temple.

sentences.zh: 群臣皆頓首言曰：「古者天子七廟，諸侯五，大夫三，雖萬世世不軼毀。

translations.text: All the assembled ministers bowed their heads and said: "In ancient times the Son of Heaven had seven temples, feudal lords five, great officials three; even for ten thousand generations they would never be removed or destroyed.

sentences.zh: 今始皇為極廟，四海之內皆獻貢職，增犧牲，禮咸備，毋以加。

translations.text: Now the First Emperor is the supreme temple; all within the four seas present tribute and duties, increase sacrificial animals, rituals are all complete; nothing can be added.

sentences.zh: 先王廟或在西雍，或在咸陽。

translations.text: The former kings' temples are either at Western Yong or at Xianyang.

sentences.zh: 天子儀當獨奉酌祠始皇廟。

translations.text: According to the Son of Heaven's ritual protocol, he should uniquely offer libations and make offerings at the First Emperor's temple.

sentences.zh: 自襄公已下軼毀。

translations.text: From Xianggong downward they may be removed and destroyed.

sentences.zh: 所置凡七廟。

translations.text: In total seven temples were established.

sentences.zh: 群臣以禮進祠，以尊始皇廟為帝者祖廟。

translations.text: The assembled ministers according to ritual advance to make offerings, honoring the First Emperor's temple as the ancestral temple of the emperor.

The emperor again refers to himself as 'zhen.'" "

translations.text: The Second Emperor plotted with Zhao Gao, saying: "I am young and have just ascended the throne; the black-headed people have not yet gathered and submitted.

sentences.zh: 先帝巡行郡縣，以示彊，威服海內。

translations.text: The former emperor toured the commanderies and counties to show strength and awe all within the seas.

sentences.zh: 今晏然不巡行，即見弱，毋以臣畜天下。」

translations.text: In spring, the Second Emperor traveled east through the commanderies and counties; Li Si accompanied him.

He then went to Liaodong and returned.

sentences.zh: 於是二世乃遵用趙高，申法令。

translations.text: Thereupon the Second Emperor followed and employed Zhao Gao, tightening laws and decrees.

sentences.zh: 乃陰與趙高謀曰：「大臣不服，官吏尚彊，及諸公子必與我爭，為之柰何？」

translations.text: He then secretly plotted with Zhao Gao, saying: "The great ministers do not submit, officials are still strong, and the various princes will surely contend with me; what should I do about this?"

sentences.zh: 高曰：「臣固願言而未敢也。

translations.text: Gao said: "I have long wished to speak but have not dared.

sentences.zh: 先帝之大臣，皆天下累世名貴人也，積功勞世以相傳久矣。

translations.text: The former emperor's great ministers are all people from families renowned and noble for generations throughout the land, with accumulated achievements and service transmitted from generation to generation for a long time.

sentences.zh: 今高素小賤，陛下幸稱舉，令在上位，管中事。

translations.text: Now I, Gao, am of lowly origin; Your Majesty graciously promoted me, placing me in a high position, managing internal affairs.

sentences.zh: 大臣鞅鞅，特以貌從臣，其心實不服。

translations.text: The great ministers are resentful and discontent, only outwardly following me as minister; in their hearts they truly do not submit.

sentences.zh: 今上出，不因此時案郡縣守尉有罪者誅之，上以振威天下，下以除去上生平所不可者。

translations.text: Now that the superior has gone out, if you do not use this time to investigate commandery and county governors and commandants with crimes and execute them, above you can demonstrate your awesome power to all under Heaven, below you can eliminate those from the superior's life whom you cannot tolerate.

sentences.zh: 今時不師文而決於武力，願陛下遂從時毋疑，即群臣不及謀。

translations.text: Now is not the time to model on civil culture but to decide by martial force; I hope Your Majesty will follow the times without hesitation, and the assembled ministers will not have time to plot.

sentences.zh: 明主收舉餘民，賤者貴之，貧者富之，遠者近之，則上下集而國安矣。」
