sentences.zh: 二世曰：「善。」

translations.text: The Second Emperor said: "Good."

sentences.zh: 乃行誅大臣及諸公子，以罪過連逮少近官三郎，無得立者，而六公子戮死於杜。

translations.text: He then executed great ministers and various princes; due to collective punishment for crimes, arrests reached junior palace officials of the three ranks of attendants, none could be installed, and six princes were executed at Du.

sentences.zh: 公子將閭昆弟三人囚於內宮，議其罪獨後。

translations.text: Prince Jianglü and his two brothers were imprisoned in the inner palace and their crimes were to be deliberated later.

sentences.zh: 二世使使令將閭曰：「公子不臣，罪當死，吏致法焉。」

translations.text: The Second Emperor sent an envoy to order Jianglü: "Prince, you have been disloyal; your crime merits death; officials will apply the law."

sentences.zh: 將閭曰：「闕廷之禮，吾未嘗敢不從賓贊也；

translations.text: Jianglü said: "In court rituals, I have never dared not follow protocol as a guest;

sentences.zh: 廊廟之位，吾未嘗敢失節也；

translations.text: in halls and temples, I have never dared lose propriety;

sentences.zh: 受命應對，吾未嘗敢失辭也。

translations.text: in receiving commands and responding to them, I have never dared speak improperly.

sentences.zh: 何謂不臣？

translations.text: How am I disloyal?

sentences.zh: 願聞罪而死。」

translations.text: I wish to hear my crime before dying."

sentences.zh: 使者曰：「臣不得與謀，奉書從事。」

translations.text: The envoy said: "I cannot discuss the plot; I am only carrying out the document."

sentences.zh: 將閭乃仰天大呼天者三，曰：「天乎！

translations.text: Jianglü then looked up to Heaven and cried out three times, saying: "Heaven!

sentences.zh: 吾無罪！」

translations.text: I am innocent!"

sentences.zh: 昆弟三人皆流涕拔劍自殺。

translations.text: The three brothers all shed tears, drew their swords, and committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 宗室振恐。

translations.text: The royal clan was alarmed and fearful.

sentences.zh: 群臣諫者以為誹謗，大吏持祿取容，黔首振恐。

translations.text: Ministers who remonstrated were considered slanderous; great officials clung to salaries and sought favor; the black-headed people were alarmed and fearful.

Thereupon the Second Emperor followed and employed Zhao Gao, tightening laws and decrees. He then secretly plotted with Zhao Gao, saying: "The great ministers do not submit, officials are still strong, and the various princes will surely contend with me; what should I do about this?" Gao said: "I have long wished to speak but have not dared. The former emperor's great ministers are all people from families renowned and noble for generations throughout the land, with accumulated achievements and service transmitted from generation to generation for a long time. Now I, Gao, am of lowly origin; Your Majesty graciously promoted me, placing me in a high position, managing internal affairs. The great ministers are resentful and discontent, only outwardly following me as minister; in their hearts they truly do not submit. Now that the superior has gone out, if you do not use this time to investigate commandery and county governors and commandants with crimes and execute them, above you can demonstrate your awesome power to all under Heaven, below you can eliminate those from the superior's life whom you cannot tolerate. Now is not the time to model on civil culture but to decide by martial force; I hope Your Majesty will follow the times without hesitation, and the assembled ministers will not have time to plot. If a brilliant lord gathers and elevates the remaining people, ennobles the base, enriches the poor, draws near the distant, then above and below will unite and the state will be secure." The Second Emperor said: "Good." He then executed great ministers and various princes; due to collective punishment for crimes, arrests reached junior palace officials of the three ranks of attendants, none could be installed, and six princes were executed at Du. Prince Jianglü and his two brothers were imprisoned in the inner palace and their crimes were to be deliberated later. The Second Emperor sent an envoy to order Jianglü: "Prince, you have been disloyal; your crime merits death; officials will apply the law." Jianglü said: "In court rituals, I have never dared not follow protocol as a guest; in halls and temples, I have never dared lose propriety; in receiving commands and responding to them, I have never dared speak improperly. How am I disloyal? I wish to hear my crime before dying." The envoy said: "I cannot discuss the plot; I am only carrying out the document." Jianglü then looked up to Heaven and cried out three times, saying: "Heaven! I am innocent!" The three brothers all shed tears, drew their swords, and committed suicide. The royal clan was alarmed and fearful. Ministers who remonstrated were considered slanderous; great officials clung to salaries and sought favor; the black-headed people were alarmed and fearful.

sentences.zh: 四月，二世還至咸陽，曰：「先帝為咸陽朝廷小，故營阿房宮為室堂。

translations.text: In the fourth month, the Second Emperor returned to Xianyang and said: "The former emperor considered the Xianyang court too small, so he built Epang Palace as halls.

sentences.zh: 未就，會上崩，罷其作者，復土酈山。

translations.text: It was not yet completed when the emperor died; the workers were dismissed and returned to bury at Lishan.

sentences.zh: 酈山事大畢，今釋阿房宮弗就，則是章先帝舉事過也。」

translations.text: The Lishan project is now greatly completed; if we now abandon Epang Palace and do not complete it, this would proclaim that the former emperor's undertaking was an error."

sentences.zh: 復作阿房宮。

translations.text: He resumed work on Epang Palace.

sentences.zh: 外撫四夷，如始皇計。

translations.text: Externally he pacified the four barbarians, following the First Emperor's plans.

sentences.zh: 盡徵其材士五萬人為屯衛咸陽，令教射狗馬禽獸。

translations.text: He mobilized all their skilled warriors, fifty thousand men, to serve as garrison guards at Xianyang, ordering them to practice shooting at dogs, horses, and wild beasts.

sentences.zh: 當食者多，度不足，下調郡縣轉輸菽粟芻稿，皆令自齎糧食，咸陽三百里內不得食其穀。

translations.text: Those who needed to be fed were many; calculating it was insufficient, he ordered commanderies and counties to transport beans, grain, fodder, and hay, all requiring them to bring their own provisions; within three hundred li of Xianyang they could not eat their own grain.

sentences.zh: 用法益刻深。

translations.text: The application of law became increasingly severe and harsh.

In the fourth month, the Second Emperor returned to Xianyang and said: "The former emperor considered the Xianyang court too small, so he built Epang Palace as halls. It was not yet completed when the emperor died; the workers were dismissed and returned to bury at Lishan. The Lishan project is now greatly completed; if we now abandon Epang Palace and do not complete it, this would proclaim that the former emperor's undertaking was an error." He resumed work on Epang Palace. Externally he pacified the four barbarians, following the First Emperor's plans. He mobilized all their skilled warriors, fifty thousand men, to serve as garrison guards at Xianyang, ordering them to practice shooting at dogs, horses, and wild beasts. Those who needed to be fed were many; calculating it was insufficient, he ordered commanderies and counties to transport beans, grain, fodder, and hay, all requiring them to bring their own provisions; within three hundred li of Xianyang they could not eat their own grain. The application of law became increasingly severe and harsh.

sentences.zh: 七月，戍卒陳勝等反故荊地，為「張楚」。

translations.text: In the seventh month, garrison soldiers Chen Sheng and others rebelled in the former Jing territory, calling themselves 'Zhang Chu.'

sentences.zh: 勝自立為楚王，居陳，遣諸將徇地。

translations.text: Sheng proclaimed himself King of Chu, resided at Chen, and sent various generals to seize territory.

sentences.zh: 山東郡縣少年苦秦吏，皆殺其守尉令丞反，以應陳涉，相立為侯王，合從西鄉，名為伐秦，不可勝數也。

translations.text: Young men in Shandong commanderies and counties, suffering under Qin officials, all killed their governors, commandants, magistrates, and assistants and rebelled to respond to Chen She; they mutually proclaimed themselves lords and kings, formed vertical alliances facing west, claiming to attack Qin; their numbers were countless.

sentences.zh: 謁者使東方來，以反者聞二世。

translations.text: An emissary sent to the east returned and reported the rebels to the Second Emperor.

sentences.zh: 二世怒，下吏。

translations.text: The Second Emperor was angry and imprisoned the official.

sentences.zh: 後使者至，上問，對曰：「群盜，郡守尉方逐捕，今盡得，不足憂。」

translations.text: When later envoys arrived, the emperor asked and they replied: "They are bandits; the commandery governors and commandants are pursuing and capturing them; now all have been caught; this is not worth worrying about."

sentences.zh: 上悅。

translations.text: The emperor was pleased.

sentences.zh: 武臣自立為趙王，魏咎為魏王，田儋為齊王。

translations.text: Wu Chen proclaimed himself King of Zhao, Wei Jiu as King of Wei, Tian Dan as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 沛公起沛。

translations.text: The Duke of Pei rose at Pei.

sentences.zh: 項梁舉兵會稽郡。

translations.text: Xiang Liang raised troops in Kuaiji Commandery.

In the seventh month, garrison soldiers Chen Sheng and others rebelled in the former Jing territory, calling themselves 'Zhang Chu.' Sheng proclaimed himself King of Chu, resided at Chen, and sent various generals to seize territory. Young men in Shandong commanderies and counties, suffering under Qin officials, all killed their governors, commandants, magistrates, and assistants and rebelled to respond to Chen She; they mutually proclaimed themselves lords and kings, formed vertical alliances facing west, claiming to attack Qin; their numbers were countless. An emissary sent to the east returned and reported the rebels to the Second Emperor. The Second Emperor was angry and imprisoned the official. When later envoys arrived, the emperor asked and they replied: "They are bandits; the commandery governors and commandants are pursuing and capturing them; now all have been caught; this is not worth worrying about." The emperor was pleased. Wu Chen proclaimed himself King of Zhao, Wei Jiu as King of Wei, Tian Dan as King of Qi. The Duke of Pei rose at Pei. Xiang Liang raised troops in Kuaiji Commandery.

sentences.zh: 二年冬，陳涉所遣周章等將西至戲，兵數十萬。

translations.text: In the winter of the second year, Zhou Zhang and others sent by Chen She led their forces west to Xi; their troops numbered in the hundreds of thousands.

sentences.zh: 二世大驚，與群臣謀曰：「柰何？」

translations.text: The Second Emperor was greatly alarmed and plotted with the assembled ministers, saying: "What should be done?"

sentences.zh: 少府章邯曰：「盜已至，眾彊，今發近縣不及矣。

translations.text: Junior Commandant Zhang Han said: "The bandits have already arrived in great strength; mobilizing nearby counties will not be in time.

sentences.zh: 酈山徒多，請赦之，授兵以擊之。」

translations.text: The Lishan convicts are numerous; I request to pardon them, give them weapons, and use them to attack."

sentences.zh: 二世乃大赦天下，使章邯將，擊破周章軍而走，遂殺章曹陽。

translations.text: The Second Emperor then granted a great amnesty throughout the land and sent Zhang Han to command; he defeated Zhou Zhang's army which fled, then killed Zhang at Caoyang.

sentences.zh: 二世益遣長史司馬欣、董翳佐章邯擊盜，殺陳勝城父，破項梁定陶，滅魏咎臨濟。

translations.text: The Second Emperor further sent Chief Clerk Sima Xin and Dong Yi to assist Zhang Han in attacking the bandits; they killed Chen Sheng at Chengfu, defeated Xiang Liang at Dingtao, and destroyed Wei Jiu at Linji.

sentences.zh: 楚地盜名將已死，章邯乃北渡河，擊趙王歇等於鉅鹿。

translations.text: The bandit leaders of the Chu territory having all died, Zhang Han then crossed the Yellow River northward and attacked King Xie of Zhao and others at Julu.

In the winter of the second year, Zhou Zhang and others sent by Chen She led their forces west to Xi; their troops numbered in the hundreds of thousands. The Second Emperor was greatly alarmed and plotted with the assembled ministers, saying: "What should be done?" Junior Commandant Zhang Han said: "The bandits have already arrived in great strength; mobilizing nearby counties will not be in time. The Lishan convicts are numerous; I request to pardon them, give them weapons, and use them to attack." The Second Emperor then granted a great amnesty throughout the land and sent Zhang Han to command; he defeated Zhou Zhang's army which fled, then killed Zhang at Caoyang. The Second Emperor further sent Chief Clerk Sima Xin and Dong Yi to assist Zhang Han in attacking the bandits; they killed Chen Sheng at Chengfu, defeated Xiang Liang at Dingtao, and destroyed Wei Jiu at Linji. The bandit leaders of the Chu territory having all died, Zhang Han then crossed the Yellow River northward and attacked King Xie of Zhao and others at Julu.

sentences.zh: 趙高說二世曰：「先帝臨制天下久，故群臣不敢為非，進邪說。

translations.text: Zhao Gao persuaded the Second Emperor, saying: "The former emperor controlled all under Heaven for a long time, so the assembled ministers dared not act improperly or advance evil proposals.

sentences.zh: 今陛下富於春秋，初即位，柰何與公卿廷決事？

translations.text: Now Your Majesty is in the prime of youth and has just ascended the throne; how can you decide matters together with dukes and ministers at court?

sentences.zh: 事即有誤，示群臣短也。

translations.text: If affairs have errors, this shows the assembled ministers your shortcomings.

sentences.zh: 天子稱朕，固不聞聲。」

translations.text: The Son of Heaven is called 'zhen'; naturally his voice is not heard."

sentences.zh: 於是二世常居禁中，與高決諸事。

translations.text: Thereupon the Second Emperor constantly remained within the forbidden palace, deciding all affairs with Gao.

sentences.zh: 其後公卿希得朝見，盜賊益多，而關中卒發東擊盜者毋已。

translations.text: Thereafter dukes and ministers rarely obtained audience; bandits and thieves increased further, while troops from Guanzhong mobilized eastward to attack bandits without end.

sentences.zh: 右丞相去疾、左丞相斯、將軍馮劫進諫曰：「關東群盜并起，秦發兵誅擊，所殺亡甚眾，然猶不止。

translations.text: Right Prime Minister Quji, Left Prime Minister Si, and General Feng Jie came forward to remonstrate, saying: "Bandits east of the passes have risen together; Qin mobilizes troops to execute and attack them; those killed and lost are very numerous, yet still they do not stop.

sentences.zh: 盜多，皆以戌漕轉作事苦，賦稅大也。

translations.text: Bandits are numerous all because garrison service, grain transport, and construction work are bitter, and taxes are heavy.

sentences.zh: 請且止阿房宮作者，減省四邊戍轉。」

translations.text: We request temporarily halting work on Epang Palace and reducing border garrison transport to the four frontiers."

sentences.zh: 二世曰：「吾聞之韓子曰：『堯舜采椽不刮，茅茨不翦，飯土塯，啜土形，雖監門之養，不觳於此。

translations.text: The Second Emperor said: "I have heard from Hanzi who said: 'Yao and Shun's rafters were not scraped, thatched roofs not trimmed, they ate from earthen bowls and drank from earthen vessels; even the sustenance of a gate guard was no worse than this.

sentences.zh: 禹鑿龍門，通大夏，決河亭水，放之海，身自持筑臿，脛毋毛，臣虜之勞不烈於此矣。』

translations.text: Yu dug through Dragon Gate, opened the Great Xia, broke through river pavilions and waters, releasing them to the sea, personally holding the rammer and spade, his shins without hair; the labor of slaves and servants was not more severe than this.'

sentences.zh: 凡所為貴有天下者，得肆意極欲，主重明法，下不敢為非，以制御海內矣。

translations.text: The reason it is noble to possess all under Heaven is to be able to indulge one's will to the utmost; the lord emphasizes and clarifies laws, so those below dare not act improperly, thereby controlling all within the seas.

sentences.zh: 夫虞、夏之主，貴為天子，親處窮苦之實，以徇百姓，尚何於法？

translations.text: The lords of Yu and Xia, though noble as Sons of Heaven, personally dwelt in actual poverty and hardship to serve the hundred clans; what need did they have for laws and standards?

sentences.zh: 朕尊萬乘，毋其實，吾欲造千乘之駕，萬乘之屬，充吾號名。

translations.text: I am honored with ten thousand chariots without their reality; I want to create the carriages of a thousand chariots and the attributes of ten thousand chariots to fulfill my title and name.

sentences.zh: 且先帝起諸侯，兼天下，天下已定，外攘四夷以安邊竟，作宮室以章得意，而君觀先帝功業有緒。

translations.text: Moreover, the former emperor rose from among the feudal lords and unified all under Heaven; all under Heaven having been settled, externally he drove out the four barbarians to secure the borders, built palaces to proclaim his satisfaction, and you observe the former emperor's achievements and enterprises having order.

sentences.zh: 今朕即位二年之閒，群盜并起，君不能禁，又欲罷先帝之所為，是上毋以報先帝，次不為朕盡忠力，何以在位？」

translations.text: Now in the two years since I ascended the throne, bandits have risen together; you cannot prohibit them, and moreover you want to stop what the former emperor was doing; above this does not repay the former emperor, below you do not exhaust loyal effort for me; why do you hold positions?"

sentences.zh: 下去疾、斯、劫吏，案責他罪。

translations.text: He handed Quji, Si, and Jie over to officials, who investigated and charged them with other crimes.

sentences.zh: 去疾、劫曰：「將相不辱。」

translations.text: Quji and Jie said: "Generals and prime ministers should not be humiliated."

sentences.zh: 自殺。

translations.text: They committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 斯卒囚，就五刑。

translations.text: Si was finally imprisoned and subjected to the five punishments.

Zhao Gao persuaded the Second Emperor, saying: "The former emperor controlled all under Heaven for a long time, so the assembled ministers dared not act improperly or advance evil proposals. Now Your Majesty is in the prime of youth and has just ascended the throne; how can you decide matters together with dukes and ministers at court? If affairs have errors, this shows the assembled ministers your shortcomings. The Son of Heaven is called 'zhen'; naturally his voice is not heard." Thereupon the Second Emperor constantly remained within the forbidden palace, deciding all affairs with Gao. Thereafter dukes and ministers rarely obtained audience; bandits and thieves increased further, while troops from Guanzhong mobilized eastward to attack bandits without end. Right Prime Minister Quji, Left Prime Minister Si, and General Feng Jie came forward to remonstrate, saying: "Bandits east of the passes have risen together; Qin mobilizes troops to execute and attack them; those killed and lost are very numerous, yet still they do not stop. Bandits are numerous all because garrison service, grain transport, and construction work are bitter, and taxes are heavy. We request temporarily halting work on Epang Palace and reducing border garrison transport to the four frontiers. " The Second Emperor said: "I have heard from Hanzi who said: 'Yao and Shun's rafters were not scraped, thatched roofs not trimmed, they ate from earthen bowls and drank from earthen vessels; even the sustenance of a gate guard was no worse than this. Yu dug through Dragon Gate, opened the Great Xia, broke through river pavilions and waters, releasing them to the sea, personally holding the rammer and spade, his shins without hair; the labor of slaves and servants was not more severe than this.' The reason it is noble to possess all under Heaven is to be able to indulge one's will to the utmost; the lord emphasizes and clarifies laws, so those below dare not act improperly, thereby controlling all within the seas. The lords of Yu and Xia, though noble as Sons of Heaven, personally dwelt in actual poverty and hardship to serve the hundred clans; what need did they have for laws and standards? I am honored with ten thousand chariots without their reality; I want to create the carriages of a thousand chariots and the attributes of ten thousand chariots to fulfill my title and name. Moreover, the former emperor rose from among the feudal lords and unified all under Heaven; all under Heaven having been settled, externally he drove out the four barbarians to secure the borders, built palaces to proclaim his satisfaction, and you observe the former emperor's achievements and enterprises having order. Now in the two years since I ascended the throne, bandits have risen together; you cannot prohibit them, and moreover you want to stop what the former emperor was doing; above this does not repay the former emperor, below you do not exhaust loyal effort for me; why do you hold positions?" He handed Quji, Si, and Jie over to officials, who investigated and charged them with other crimes. Quji and Jie said: "Generals and prime ministers should not be humiliated." They committed suicide. Si was finally imprisoned and subjected to the five punishments.

sentences.zh: 三年，章邯等將其卒圍鉅鹿，楚上將軍項羽將楚卒往救鉅鹿。

translations.text: In the third year, Zhang Han and others led their troops to besiege Julu; the Chu supreme general Xiang Yu led Chu troops to rescue Julu.

sentences.zh: 冬，趙高為丞相，竟案李斯殺之。

translations.text: In winter, Zhao Gao became prime minister and finally investigated Li Si and killed him.

sentences.zh: 夏，章邯等戰數卻，二世使人讓邯，邯恐，使長史欣請事。

translations.text: In summer, Zhang Han and others fought several defeats; the Second Emperor sent someone to reproach Han; Han was afraid and sent Chief Clerk Xin to request instructions.

sentences.zh: 趙高弗見，又弗信。

translations.text: Zhao Gao refused to see him and moreover did not trust him.

sentences.zh: 欣恐，亡去，高使人捕追不及。

translations.text: Xin was afraid and fled; Gao sent people to pursue and arrest him but did not catch him.

sentences.zh: 欣見邯曰：「趙高用事於中，將軍有功亦誅，無功亦誅。」

translations.text: Xin met with Han and said: "Zhao Gao handles affairs internally; whether you, general, have achievements or not, you will be executed."

sentences.zh: 項羽急擊秦軍，虜王離，邯等遂以兵降諸侯。

translations.text: Xiang Yu urgently attacked the Qin army, captured Wang Li; Han and others then surrendered with their troops to the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 八月己亥，趙高欲為亂，恐群臣不聽，乃先設驗，持鹿獻於二世，曰：「馬也。」

translations.text: On the jihai day of the eighth month, Zhao Gao wanted to create disorder but feared the assembled ministers would not obey, so he first set up a test: he presented a deer to the Second Emperor and said: "It is a horse."

sentences.zh: 二世笑曰：「丞相誤邪？

translations.text: The Second Emperor laughed and said: "Is the prime minister mistaken?

sentences.zh: 謂鹿為馬。」

translations.text: Calling a deer a horse."

sentences.zh: 問左右，左右或默，或言馬以阿順趙高。

translations.text: He asked those around him; some remained silent, some said horse to flatter and follow Zhao Gao.

sentences.zh: 或言鹿（者），高因陰中諸言鹿者以法。

translations.text: Those who said deer, Gao then secretly used the law against all who said deer.

sentences.zh: 後群臣皆畏高。

translations.text: Thereafter all the assembled ministers feared Gao.

In the third year, Zhang Han and others led their troops to besiege Julu; the Chu supreme general Xiang Yu led Chu troops to rescue Julu. In winter, Zhao Gao became prime minister and finally investigated Li Si and killed him. In summer, Zhang Han and others fought several defeats; the Second Emperor sent someone to reproach Han; Han was afraid and sent Chief Clerk Xin to request instructions. Zhao Gao refused to see him and moreover did not trust him. Xin was afraid and fled; Gao sent people to pursue and arrest him but did not catch him. Xin met with Han and said: "Zhao Gao handles affairs internally; whether you, general, have achievements or not, you will be executed." Xiang Yu urgently attacked the Qin army, captured Wang Li; Han and others then surrendered with their troops to the feudal lords. On the jihai day of the eighth month, Zhao Gao wanted to create disorder but feared the assembled ministers would not obey, so he first set up a test: he presented a deer to the Second Emperor and said: "It is a horse." The Second Emperor laughed and said: "Is the prime minister mistaken? Calling a deer a horse." He asked those around him; some remained silent, some said horse to flatter and follow Zhao Gao. Those who said deer, Gao then secretly used the law against all who said deer. Thereafter all the assembled ministers feared Gao.

sentences.zh: 高前數言「關東盜毋能為也」，及項羽虜秦將王離等鉅鹿下而前，章邯等軍數卻，上書請益助，燕、趙、齊、楚、韓、魏皆立為王，自關以東，大氐盡畔秦吏應諸侯，諸侯咸率其眾西鄉。

translations.text: Gao had previously repeatedly said 'bandits east of the passes cannot accomplish anything,' but when Xiang Yu captured Qin general Wang Li and others below Julu and advanced, Zhang Han and others' armies suffered repeated defeats; they sent memorials requesting reinforcements; Yan, Zhao, Qi, Chu, Han, and Wei all installed themselves as kings; from the passes eastward, most had rebelled against Qin officials and responded to the feudal lords; all the feudal lords led their masses westward.

sentences.zh: 沛公將數萬人已屠武關，使人私於高，高恐二世怒，誅及其身，乃謝病不朝見。

translations.text: The Duke of Pei, leading several tens of thousands, had already captured Wuguan and sent people privately to Gao; Gao feared the Second Emperor would be angry and punishment would reach him personally, so he feigned illness and did not come to court.

sentences.zh: 二世夢白虎齧其左驂馬，殺之，心不樂，怪問占夢。

translations.text: The Second Emperor dreamed that a white tiger bit off his left trace horse and killed it; his heart was uneasy, and he strangely inquired about dream interpretation.

sentences.zh: 卜曰：「涇水為祟。」

translations.text: The divination said: "The Jing River is causing calamity."

sentences.zh: 二世乃齋於望夷宮，欲祠涇，沈四白馬。

translations.text: The Second Emperor then fasted at Wangyi Palace, wishing to sacrifice to the Jing River, and sank four white horses.

sentences.zh: 使使責讓高以盜賊事。

translations.text: He sent an envoy to reproach Gao about bandit matters.

sentences.zh: 高懼，乃陰與其婿咸陽令閻樂、其弟趙成謀曰：「上不聽諫，今事急，欲歸禍於吾宗。

translations.text: Gao was afraid, so he secretly plotted with his son-in-law Yan Le, the Xianyang magistrate, and his younger brother Zhao Cheng, saying: "The emperor does not listen to remonstrances; now affairs are urgent and he wants to direct blame to my clan.

sentences.zh: 吾欲易置上，更立公子嬰。

translations.text: I want to replace the emperor and install Prince Ying.

sentences.zh: 子嬰仁儉，百姓皆載其言。」

translations.text: Prince Ying is benevolent and frugal; the hundred clans all support his words."

sentences.zh: 使郎中令為內應，詐為有大賊，令樂召吏發卒，追劫樂母置高舍。

translations.text: He had the Palace Attendant Commander serve as internal support, falsely claiming there were major bandits, had Le summon officials and mobilize troops, forcibly kidnapped Le's mother and placed her at Gao's residence.

sentences.zh: 遣樂將吏卒千餘人至望夷宮殿門，縛衛令仆射，曰：「賊入此，何不止？」

translations.text: He sent Le to lead officials and troops, over a thousand men, to the Wangyi Palace gate, bound the Guard Commander and Chief Clerk, and said: "Bandits have entered here; why did you not stop them?"

sentences.zh: 衛令曰：「周廬設卒甚謹，安得賊敢入宮？」

translations.text: The Guard Commander said: "The surrounding guardhouses and deployed troops are very vigilant; how could bandits dare enter the palace?"

sentences.zh: 樂遂斬衛令，直將吏入，行射，郎宦者大驚，或走或格，格者輒死，死者數十人。

translations.text: Le then beheaded the Guard Commander, directly led officials in, and shot as they went; palace attendants and eunuchs were greatly frightened, some fled, some resisted; those who resisted were immediately killed; dozens died.

sentences.zh: 郎中令與樂俱入，射上幄坐幃。

translations.text: The Palace Attendant Commander and Le entered together and shot at the emperor's curtained seat.

sentences.zh: 二世怒，召左右，左右皆惶擾不鬬。

translations.text: The Second Emperor was angry and summoned those around him, but all were panicked and confused and did not fight.

sentences.zh: 旁有宦者一人，侍不敢去。

translations.text: Nearby was one eunuch who attended and did not dare leave.

sentences.zh: 二世入內，謂曰：「公何不蚤告我？

translations.text: The Second Emperor entered the inner chambers and said to him: "Why did you not warn me earlier?

sentences.zh: 乃至於此！」

translations.text: Now it has come to this!"

sentences.zh: 宦者曰：「臣不敢言，故得全。

translations.text: The eunuch said: "I did not dare speak, therefore I survived.

sentences.zh: 使臣蚤言，皆已誅，安得至今？」

translations.text: Had I spoken early, I would already have been executed; how would I have reached today?"

sentences.zh: 閻樂前即二世數曰：「足下驕恣，誅殺無道，天下共畔足下，足下其自為計。」

translations.text: Yan Le came forward to the Second Emperor and enumerated his crimes: "You have been arrogant and willful, executing and killing without proper cause; all under Heaven has rebelled against you together; you should make your own decision."

sentences.zh: 二世曰：「丞相可得見否？」

translations.text: The Second Emperor said: "Can I see the prime minister?"

sentences.zh: 樂曰：「不可。」

translations.text: Le said: "No."

sentences.zh: 二世曰：「吾願得一郡為王。」

translations.text: The Second Emperor said: "I wish to obtain one commandery to be king."

sentences.zh: 弗許。

translations.text: He did not permit it.

sentences.zh: 又曰：「願為萬戶侯。」

translations.text: He said again: "I wish to be a marquis of ten thousand households."

sentences.zh: 弗許。

translations.text: He did not permit it.

sentences.zh: 曰：「願與妻子為黔首，比諸公子。」

translations.text: He said: "I wish to be a commoner with my wife and children, like the other princes."

sentences.zh: 閻樂曰：「臣受命於丞相，為天下誅足下，足下雖多言，臣不敢報。」

translations.text: Yan Le said: "I received orders from the prime minister to execute you on behalf of all under Heaven; though you speak much, I dare not relay it."

sentences.zh: 麾其兵進。

translations.text: He signaled his troops to advance.

sentences.zh: 二世自殺。

translations.text: The Second Emperor committed suicide.

Gao had previously repeatedly said 'bandits east of the passes cannot accomplish anything,' but when Xiang Yu captured Qin general Wang Li and others below Julu and advanced, Zhang Han and others' armies suffered repeated defeats; they sent memorials requesting reinforcements; Yan, Zhao, Qi, Chu, Han, and Wei all installed themselves as kings; from the passes eastward, most had rebelled against Qin officials and responded to the feudal lords; all the feudal lords led their masses westward. The Duke of Pei, leading several tens of thousands, had already captured Wuguan and sent people privately to Gao; Gao feared the Second Emperor would be angry and punishment would reach him personally, so he feigned illness and did not come to court. The Second Emperor dreamed that a white tiger bit off his left trace horse and killed it; his heart was uneasy, and he strangely inquired about dream interpretation. The divination said: "The Jing River is causing calamity." The Second Emperor then fasted at Wangyi Palace, wishing to sacrifice to the Jing River, and sank four white horses. He sent an envoy to reproach Gao about bandit matters. Gao was afraid, so he secretly plotted with his son-in-law Yan Le, the Xianyang magistrate, and his younger brother Zhao Cheng, saying: "The emperor does not listen to remonstrances; now affairs are urgent and he wants to direct blame to my clan. I want to replace the emperor and install Prince Ying. Prince Ying is benevolent and frugal; the hundred clans all support his words." He had the Palace Attendant Commander serve as internal support, falsely claiming there were major bandits, had Le summon officials and mobilize troops, forcibly kidnapped Le's mother and placed her at Gao's residence. He sent Le to lead officials and troops, over a thousand men, to the Wangyi Palace gate, bound the Guard Commander and Chief Clerk, and said: "Bandits have entered here; why did you not stop them?" The Guard Commander said: "The surrounding guardhouses and deployed troops are very vigilant; how could bandits dare enter the palace?" Le then beheaded the Guard Commander, directly led officials in, and shot as they went; palace attendants and eunuchs were greatly frightened, some fled, some resisted; those who resisted were immediately killed; dozens died. The Palace Attendant Commander and Le entered together and shot at the emperor's curtained seat. The Second Emperor was angry and summoned those around him, but all were panicked and confused and did not fight. Nearby was one eunuch who attended and did not dare leave. The Second Emperor entered the inner chambers and said to him: "Why did you not warn me earlier? Now it has come to this!" The eunuch said: "I did not dare speak, therefore I survived. Had I spoken early, I would already have been executed; how would I have reached today?" Yan Le came forward to the Second Emperor and enumerated his crimes: "You have been arrogant and willful, executing and killing without proper cause; all under Heaven has rebelled against you together; you should make your own decision." The Second Emperor said: "Can I see the prime minister?" Le said: "No." The Second Emperor said: "I wish to obtain one commandery to be king." He did not permit it. He said again: "I wish to be a marquis of ten thousand households." He did not permit it. He said: "I wish to be a commoner with my wife and children, like the other princes." Yan Le said: "I received orders from the prime minister to execute you on behalf of all under Heaven; though you speak much, I dare not relay it." He signaled his troops to advance. The Second Emperor committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 閻樂歸報趙高，趙高乃悉召諸大臣公子，告以誅二世之狀。

translations.text: Yan Le returned and reported to Zhao Gao; Zhao Gao then summoned all the great ministers and princes and informed them of the circumstances of executing the Second Emperor.

sentences.zh: 曰：「秦故王國，始皇君天下，故稱帝。

translations.text: He said: "Qin was formerly a royal state; when the First Emperor ruled all under Heaven, he was therefore called Emperor.

sentences.zh: 今六國復自立，秦地益小，乃以空名為帝，不可。

translations.text: Now the six states have again independently established themselves; Qin's territory has become smaller; to use the empty title of Emperor is not acceptable.

sentences.zh: 宜為王如故，便。」

translations.text: It would be appropriate to be king as before; this is expedient."

sentences.zh: 立二世之兄子公子嬰為秦王。

translations.text: He installed the Second Emperor's elder brother's son, Prince Ying, as King of Qin.

sentences.zh: 以黔首葬二世杜南宜春苑中。

translations.text: He had the black-headed people bury the Second Emperor in Yichun Garden south of Du.

sentences.zh: 令子嬰齋，當廟見，受王璽。

translations.text: He ordered Prince Ying to fast, when he should appear at the temple to receive the king's seal.

sentences.zh: 齋五日，子嬰與其子二人謀曰：「丞相高殺二世望夷宮，恐群臣誅之，乃詳以義立我。

translations.text: After fasting for five days, Prince Ying plotted with his two sons, saying: "Prime Minister Gao killed the Second Emperor at Wangyi Palace; fearing the assembled ministers would execute him, he pretended righteously to install me.

sentences.zh: 我聞趙高乃與楚約，滅秦宗室而王關中。

translations.text: I have heard that Zhao Gao made an agreement with Chu to destroy the Qin royal clan and rule Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 今使我齋見廟，此欲因廟中殺我。

translations.text: Now he has me fast and appear at the temple; this is wanting to kill me in the temple.

sentences.zh: 我稱病不行，丞相必自來，來則殺之。」

translations.text: I will feign illness and not go; the prime minister will surely come himself; when he comes I will kill him."

sentences.zh: 高使人請子嬰數輩，子嬰不行，高果自往，曰：「宗廟重事，王柰何不行？」

translations.text: Gao sent people to request Prince Ying several times; Prince Ying did not go; Gao indeed came himself and said: "Ancestral temple affairs are of great importance; why does the king not go?"

sentences.zh: 子嬰遂刺殺高於齋宮，三族高家以徇咸陽。

translations.text: Prince Ying then stabbed and killed Gao at the fasting palace and exterminated Gao's three clans, displaying them as a warning throughout Xianyang.

sentences.zh: 子嬰為秦王四十六日，楚將沛公破秦軍入武關，遂至霸上，使人約降子嬰。

translations.text: Prince Ying served as King of Qin for forty-six days; the Chu general Duke of Pei defeated the Qin army, entered Wuguan, and reached Beshang, sending someone to arrange Prince Ying's surrender.

sentences.zh: 子嬰即系頸以組，白馬素車，奉天子璽符，降軹道旁。

translations.text: Prince Ying then tied a cord around his neck, rode in a plain white chariot drawn by white horses, presented the Son of Heaven's seal and tallies, and surrendered by the side of Zhidao.

sentences.zh: 沛公遂入咸陽，封宮室府庫，還軍霸上。

translations.text: The Duke of Pei then entered Xianyang, sealed the palaces and treasury, and returned the army to Bashang.

sentences.zh: 居月餘，諸侯兵至，項籍為從長，殺子嬰及秦諸公子宗族。

translations.text: After dwelling for over a month, the feudal lords' armies arrived; Xiang Ji was the chief of the alliance and killed Prince Ying and all the Qin princes and royal clan.

sentences.zh: 遂屠咸陽，燒其宮室，虜其子女，收其珍寶貨財，諸侯共分之。

translations.text: He then massacred Xianyang, burned its palaces, captured its sons and daughters, and collected its precious treasures and wealth; the feudal lords divided them among themselves.

sentences.zh: 滅秦之後，各分其地為三，名曰雍王、塞王、翟王，號曰三秦。

translations.text: After destroying Qin, they each divided its territory into three, naming them King of Yong, King of Sai, and King of Di, collectively called the Three Qin.

sentences.zh: 項羽為西楚霸王，主命分天下王諸侯，秦竟滅矣。

translations.text: Xiang Yu became Hegemon-King of Western Chu, commanded and divided all under Heaven among the feudal lords as kings; Qin was finally destroyed.

sentences.zh: 後五年，天下定於漢。

translations.text: Five years later, all under Heaven was settled under Han.

Yan Le returned and reported to Zhao Gao; Zhao Gao then summoned all the great ministers and princes and informed them of the circumstances of executing the Second Emperor. He said: "Qin was formerly a royal state; when the First Emperor ruled all under Heaven, he was therefore called Emperor. Now the six states have again independently established themselves; Qin's territory has become smaller; to use the empty title of Emperor is not acceptable. It would be appropriate to be king as before; this is expedient." He installed the Second Emperor's elder brother's son, Prince Ying, as King of Qin. He had the black-headed people bury the Second Emperor in Yichun Garden south of Du. He ordered Prince Ying to fast, when he should appear at the temple to receive the king's seal. After fasting for five days, Prince Ying plotted with his two sons, saying: "Prime Minister Gao killed the Second Emperor at Wangyi Palace; fearing the assembled ministers would execute him, he pretended righteously to install me. I have heard that Zhao Gao made an agreement with Chu to destroy the Qin royal clan and rule Guanzhong. Now he has me fast and appear at the temple; this is wanting to kill me in the temple. I will feign illness and not go; the prime minister will surely come himself; when he comes I will kill him." Gao sent people to request Prince Ying several times; Prince Ying did not go; Gao indeed came himself and said: "Ancestral temple affairs are of great importance; why does the king not go?" Prince Ying then stabbed and killed Gao at the fasting palace and exterminated Gao's three clans, displaying them as a warning throughout Xianyang. Prince Ying served as King of Qin for forty-six days; the Chu general Duke of Pei defeated the Qin army, entered Wuguan, and reached Beshang, sending someone to arrange Prince Ying's surrender. Prince Ying then tied a cord around his neck, rode in a plain white chariot drawn by white horses, presented the Son of Heaven's seal and tallies, and surrendered by the side of Zhidao. The Duke of Pei then entered Xianyang, sealed the palaces and treasury, and returned the army to Bashang. After dwelling for over a month, the feudal lords' armies arrived; Xiang Ji was the chief of the alliance and killed Prince Ying and all the Qin princes and royal clan. He then massacred Xianyang, burned its palaces, captured its sons and daughters, and collected its precious treasures and wealth; the feudal lords divided them among themselves. After destroying Qin, they each divided its territory into three, naming them King of Yong, King of Sai, and King of Di, collectively called the Three Qin. Xiang Yu became Hegemon-King of Western Chu, commanded and divided all under Heaven among the feudal lords as kings; Qin was finally destroyed. Five years later, all under Heaven was settled under Han.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：秦之先伯翳，嘗有勳於唐虞之際，受土賜姓。

translations.text: The Grand Historian says: Qin's ancestor Boyi once had meritorious service during the time of Tang and Yu, received land and was granted a surname.

sentences.zh: 及殷夏之閒微散。

translations.text: Between Yin and Xia he became obscure and scattered.

sentences.zh: 至周之衰，秦興，邑于西垂。

translations.text: When Zhou declined, Qin arose, establishing a town at Western Chui.

sentences.zh: 自繆公以來，稍蠶食諸侯，竟成始皇。

translations.text: From Duke Mu onward, they gradually devoured the feudal lords bit by bit, finally producing the First Emperor.

sentences.zh: 始皇自以為功過五帝，地廣三王，而羞與之侔。

translations.text: The First Emperor considered himself to have achievements surpassing the Five Emperors and territory broader than the Three Kings, and was ashamed to be equaled with them.

sentences.zh: 善哉乎賈生推言之也！

translations.text: How excellent was Master Jia's extended reasoning!

sentences.zh: 曰：

translations.text: He said:

The Grand Historian says: Qin's ancestor Boyi once had meritorious service during the time of Tang and Yu, received land and was granted a surname. Between Yin and Xia he became obscure and scattered. When Zhou declined, Qin arose, establishing a town at Western Chui. From Duke Mu onward, they gradually devoured the feudal lords bit by bit, finally producing the First Emperor. The First Emperor considered himself to have achievements surpassing the Five Emperors and territory broader than the Three Kings, and was ashamed to be equaled with them. How excellent was Master Jia's extended reasoning! He said:

sentences.zh: 秦并兼諸侯山東三十餘郡，繕津關，據險塞，修甲兵而守之。

translations.text: Qin annexed the feudal lords of Shandong into over thirty commanderies, repaired ferry crossings and passes, occupied strategic passes and fortifications, and maintained armor and weapons to guard them.

sentences.zh: 然陳涉以戍卒散亂之眾數百，奮臂大呼，不用弓戟之兵，鉏櫌白梃，望屋而食，橫行天下。

translations.text: Yet Chen She with a scattered and chaotic crowd of garrison soldiers numbering in the hundreds, raising his arm and shouting loudly, without using the weapons of bows and halberds, with only hoes, rakes, and white clubs, taking food wherever they saw houses, rampaged throughout the land.

sentences.zh: 秦人阻險不守，關梁不闔，長戟不刺，彊弩不射。

translations.text: The Qin people blocked strategic passes but did not guard them; passes and bridges were not closed, long halberds did not stab, and strong crossbows did not shoot.

sentences.zh: 楚師深入，戰於鴻門，曾無藩籬之艱。

translations.text: The Chu army deeply penetrated and fought at Hongmen, without encountering even the difficulty of hedges and fences.

sentences.zh: 於是山東大擾，諸侯并起，豪俊相立。

translations.text: Thereupon Shandong was greatly disturbed, feudal lords rose together, and heroes mutually established themselves.

sentences.zh: 秦使章邯將而東征，章邯因以三軍之眾要市於外，以謀其上。

translations.text: Qin sent Zhang Han to command and march east; Zhang Han then used his three armies to bargain from outside to plot against his superior.

sentences.zh: 群臣之不信，可見於此矣。

translations.text: That the assembled ministers were not trusted can be seen from this.

sentences.zh: 子嬰立，遂不寤。

translations.text: When Prince Ying was installed, he still did not awaken.

sentences.zh: 藉使子嬰有庸主之材，僅得中佐，山東雖亂，秦之地可全而有，宗廟之祀未當絕也。

translations.text: If Prince Ying had had the abilities of an ordinary lord and merely obtained moderate assistance, though Shandong was in chaos, Qin's territory could have been preserved intact, and the ancestral temple sacrifices need not have been cut off.

Qin annexed the feudal lords of Shandong into over thirty commanderies, repaired ferry crossings and passes, occupied strategic passes and fortifications, and maintained armor and weapons to guard them. Yet Chen She with a scattered and chaotic crowd of garrison soldiers numbering in the hundreds, raising his arm and shouting loudly, without using the weapons of bows and halberds, with only hoes, rakes, and white clubs, taking food wherever they saw houses, rampaged throughout the land. The Qin people blocked strategic passes but did not guard them; passes and bridges were not closed, long halberds did not stab, and strong crossbows did not shoot. The Chu army deeply penetrated and fought at Hongmen, without encountering even the difficulty of hedges and fences. Thereupon Shandong was greatly disturbed, feudal lords rose together, and heroes mutually established themselves. Qin sent Zhang Han to command and march east; Zhang Han then used his three armies to bargain from outside to plot against his superior. That the assembled ministers were not trusted can be seen from this. When Prince Ying was installed, he still did not awaken. If Prince Ying had had the abilities of an ordinary lord and merely obtained moderate assistance, though Shandong was in chaos, Qin's territory could have been preserved intact, and the ancestral temple sacrifices need not have been cut off.

sentences.zh: 秦地被山帶河以為固，四塞之國也。

translations.text: Qin's territory was backed by mountains and bordered by rivers as natural defenses; it was a state protected by four barriers.

sentences.zh: 自繆公以來，至於秦王，二十餘君，常為諸侯雄。

translations.text: From Duke Mu onward to the King of Qin, over twenty lords constantly were the most powerful among feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 豈世世賢哉？

translations.text: Was every generation sage?

sentences.zh: 其勢居然也。

translations.text: No, the strategic position was naturally thus.

sentences.zh: 且天下嘗同心并力而攻秦矣。

translations.text: Moreover, all under Heaven once united their hearts and combined their forces to attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 當此之世，賢智并列，良將行其師，賢相通其謀，然困於阻險而不能進，秦乃延入戰而為之開關，百萬之徒逃北而遂壞。

translations.text: At that time, the wise and intelligent were arrayed together, excellent generals led their armies, worthy prime ministers implemented their strategies, yet they were obstructed by dangerous terrain and could not advance; Qin then drew them into battle and opened the passes for them; millions of their troops fled northward and were thus defeated.

sentences.zh: 豈勇力智慧不足哉？

translations.text: Was it that courage, strength, and wisdom were insufficient?

sentences.zh: 形不利，勢不便也。

translations.text: No, the terrain was not favorable and the strategic position not advantageous.

sentences.zh: 秦小邑并大城，守險塞而軍，高壘毋戰，閉關據阨，荷戟而守之。

translations.text: If Qin had defended small towns and garrisoned large cities, guarded strategic passes and stationed troops, raised high ramparts without engaging in battle, closed passes and occupied chokepoints, shouldering halberds to guard them—

sentences.zh: 諸侯起於匹夫，以利合，非有素王之行也。

translations.text: The feudal lords arose from among commoners, united by profit, without the conduct of legitimate kingship.

sentences.zh: 其交未親，其下未附，名為亡秦，其實利之也。

translations.text: Their alliances were not yet close, their subordinates not yet attached; in name they sought to destroy Qin, but in reality each sought their own profit.

sentences.zh: 彼見秦阻之難犯也，必退師。

translations.text: When they saw how difficult Qin's barriers were to attack, they would surely retreat.

sentences.zh: 安土息民，以待其敝，收弱扶罷，以令大國之君，不患不得意於海內。

translations.text: Settling the land and resting the people, waiting for their exhaustion, gathering the weak and supporting the weary, to order the lords of great states—they would not worry about not achieving their will within the seas.

sentences.zh: 貴為天子，富有天下，而身為禽者，其救敗非也。

translations.text: Noble as Son of Heaven, wealthy possessing all under Heaven, yet his body became a captive—this was because his method for averting defeat was wrong.

Qin's territory was backed by mountains and bordered by rivers as natural defenses; it was a state protected by four barriers. From Duke Mu onward to the King of Qin, over twenty lords constantly were the most powerful among feudal lords. Was every generation sage? No, the strategic position was naturally thus. Moreover, all under Heaven once united their hearts and combined their forces to attack Qin. At that time, the wise and intelligent were arrayed together, excellent generals led their armies, worthy prime ministers implemented their strategies, yet they were obstructed by dangerous terrain and could not advance; Qin then drew them into battle and opened the passes for them; millions of their troops fled northward and were thus defeated. Was it that courage, strength, and wisdom were insufficient? No, the terrain was not favorable and the strategic position not advantageous. If Qin had defended small towns and garrisoned large cities, guarded strategic passes and stationed troops, raised high ramparts without engaging in battle, closed passes and occupied chokepoints, shouldering halberds to guard them— The feudal lords arose from among commoners, united by profit, without the conduct of legitimate kingship. Their alliances were not yet close, their subordinates not yet attached; in name they sought to destroy Qin, but in reality each sought their own profit. When they saw how difficult Qin's barriers were to attack, they would surely retreat. Settling the land and resting the people, waiting for their exhaustion, gathering the weak and supporting the weary, to order the lords of great states—they would not worry about not achieving their will within the seas. Noble as Son of Heaven, wealthy possessing all under Heaven, yet his body became a captive—this was because his method for averting defeat was wrong.

sentences.zh: 秦王足己不問，遂過而不變。

translations.text: The Qin king was self-satisfied and did not inquire, thereby making errors and not changing.

sentences.zh: 二世受之，因而不改，暴虐以重禍。

translations.text: The Second Emperor inherited this and consequently did not reform; violent and tyrannical, he compounded the disaster.

sentences.zh: 子嬰孤立無親，危弱無輔。

translations.text: Prince Ying stood isolated without relatives, endangered and weak without support.

sentences.zh: 三主惑而終身不悟，亡，不亦宜乎？

translations.text: The three lords were confused and never awakened their entire lives; that they perished, was this not appropriate?

sentences.zh: 當此時也，世非無深慮知化之士也，然所以不敢盡忠拂過者，秦俗多忌諱之禁，忠言未卒於口而身為戮沒矣。

translations.text: At this time, the age was not without deeply thoughtful scholars who understood transformation, but the reason they dared not exhaust loyalty and brush aside faults was that Qin customs had many taboos and prohibitions; loyal words not yet finished from the mouth and the body was already executed and destroyed.

sentences.zh: 故使天下之士，傾耳而聽，重足而立，拑口而不言。

translations.text: Therefore all the scholars throughout the land inclined their ears to listen, stood hesitantly with feet together, and clamped their mouths shut without speaking.

sentences.zh: 是以三主失道，忠臣不敢諫，智士不敢謀，天下已亂，姦不上聞，豈不哀哉！

translations.text: Therefore the three lords lost the Way, loyal ministers dared not remonstrate, wise scholars dared not plan; all under Heaven was already in chaos, yet treachery was not reported above; is this not sorrowful!

sentences.zh: 先王知雍蔽之傷國也，故置公卿大夫士，以飾法設刑，而天下治。

translations.text: The former kings knew that obstruction and concealment harmed the state, so they established dukes, ministers, great officials, and lesser officials to adorn laws and establish punishments, and all under Heaven was governed.

sentences.zh: 其彊也，禁暴誅亂而天下服。

translations.text: When strong, they prohibited violence and punished chaos, and all under Heaven submitted.

sentences.zh: 其弱也，五伯征而諸侯從。

translations.text: When it was weak, the Five Hegemons led campaigns and the feudal lords followed.

sentences.zh: 其削也，內守外附而社稷存。

translations.text: When it was reduced in power, internally it guarded itself, externally others remained attached, and the altars of soil and grain were preserved.

sentences.zh: 故秦之盛也，繁法嚴刑而天下振；

translations.text: Thus when Qin was at its peak with numerous laws and severe punishments, all under Heaven trembled;

sentences.zh: 及其衰也，百姓怨望而海內畔矣。

translations.text: when it declined, the hundred clans were resentful and discontented, and all within the seas rebelled.

sentences.zh: 故周五序得其道，而千餘歲不絕。

translations.text: Thus Zhou with its five ranks of nobility obtained the Way and lasted over a thousand years without being cut off.

sentences.zh: 秦本末并失，故不長久。

translations.text: Qin failed in both beginning and end, and therefore did not last long.

sentences.zh: 由此觀之，安危之統相去遠矣。

translations.text: Viewing it from this perspective, the patterns of safety and danger are vastly different.

sentences.zh: 野諺曰「前事之不忘，後事之師也」。

translations.text: A rustic proverb says: 'Not forgetting past affairs, they are the teacher of future affairs.'

sentences.zh: 是以君子為國，觀之上古，驗之當世，參以人事，察盛衰之理，審權勢之宜，去就有序，變化有時，故曠日長久而社稷安矣。

translations.text: Therefore when the superior person governs a state, he observes high antiquity, verifies in the present age, considers human affairs, examines the principles of prosperity and decline, carefully considers the propriety of authority and power; going and staying have order, transformation and change have proper times; thus over long durations the altars of soil and grain are secure.

The Qin king was self-satisfied and did not inquire, thereby making errors and not changing. The Second Emperor inherited this and consequently did not reform; violent and tyrannical, he compounded the disaster. Prince Ying stood isolated without relatives, endangered and weak without support. The three lords were confused and never awakened their entire lives; that they perished, was this not appropriate? At this time, the age was not without deeply thoughtful scholars who understood transformation, but the reason they dared not exhaust loyalty and brush aside faults was that Qin customs had many taboos and prohibitions; loyal words not yet finished from the mouth and the body was already executed and destroyed. Therefore all the scholars throughout the land inclined their ears to listen, stood hesitantly with feet together, and clamped their mouths shut without speaking. Therefore the three lords lost the Way, loyal ministers dared not remonstrate, wise scholars dared not plan; all under Heaven was already in chaos, yet treachery was not reported above; is this not sorrowful! When it was reduced in power, internally it guarded itself, externally others remained attached, and the altars of soil and grain were preserved. Thus when Qin was at its peak with numerous laws and severe punishments, all under Heaven trembled; when it declined, the hundred clans were resentful and discontented, and all within the seas rebelled. Therefore when the superior person governs a state, he observes high antiquity, verifies in the present age, considers human affairs, examines the principles of prosperity and decline, carefully considers the propriety of authority and power; going and staying have order, transformation and change have proper times; thus over long durations the altars of soil and grain are secure.

sentences.zh: 秦孝公據殽函之固，擁雍州之地，君臣固守而窺周室，有席卷天下，包舉宇內，囊括四海之意，并吞八荒之心。

translations.text: Duke Xiao of Qin occupied the stronghold of Xiao and Han and controlled the lands of Yongzhou; lord and ministers firmly defended their position while looking covetously upon the Zhou royal house, harboring the intention to roll up all under Heaven, embrace the universe, encompass the four seas, and the ambition to swallow the eight wastes.

sentences.zh: 當是時，商君佐之，內立法度，務耕織，修守戰之備，外連衡而鬬諸侯，於是秦人拱手而取西河之外。

translations.text: At that time, Shang Yang assisted him: internally establishing laws and regulations, promoting agriculture and weaving, maintaining defensive and offensive preparations; externally using horizontal alliances to make the feudal lords fight each other; thereupon the Qin people effortlessly took the territory west of the Yellow River.

At that time, Shang Yang assisted him: internally establishing laws and regulations, promoting agriculture and weaving, maintaining defensive and offensive preparations; externally using horizontal alliances to make the feudal lords fight each other; thereupon the Qin people effortlessly took the territory west of the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 孝公既沒，惠王、武王蒙故業，因遺冊，南兼漢中，西舉巴、蜀，東割膏腴之地，收要害之郡。

translations.text: After Duke Xiao died, Kings Hui and Wu inherited the old enterprise and followed his established policies, annexing Hanzhong to the south, taking Ba and Shu to the west, cutting off fertile lands to the east, and gathering strategic commanderies.

sentences.zh: 諸侯恐懼，會盟而謀弱秦，不愛珍器重寶肥美之地，以致天下之士，合從締交，相與為一。

translations.text: The feudal lords were afraid and fearful; they held meetings and formed alliances to plot the weakening of Qin, not begrudging precious vessels, valuable treasures, or fertile rich lands to attract scholars from throughout the land, forming vertical alliances and bonds, mutually uniting as one.

sentences.zh: 當是時，齊有孟嘗，趙有平原，楚有春申，魏有信陵。

translations.text: At that time, Qi had Mengchang, Zhao had Pingyuan, Chu had Chunshen, Wei had Xinling.

sentences.zh: 此四君者，皆明知而忠信，寬厚而愛人，尊賢重士，約從離衡，并韓、魏、燕、楚、齊、趙、宋、衛、中山之眾。

translations.text: These four lords were all intelligent and trustworthy, generous and magnanimous, loved their people, respected the worthy, and esteemed men of ability; they formed vertical alliances while disrupting horizontal ones, uniting the masses of Han, Wei, Yan, Chu, Qi, Zhao, Song, Wei, and Zhongshan.

sentences.zh: 於是六國之士有寧越、徐尚、蘇秦、杜赫之屬為之謀，齊明、周最、陳軫、昭滑、樓緩、翟景、蘇厲、樂毅之徒通其意，吳起、孫臏、帶佗、兒良、王廖、田忌、廉頗、趙奢之朋制其兵。

translations.text: Thereupon among the scholars of the Six States were Ning Yue, Xu Shang, Su Qin, Du He and their associates who planned for them; Qi Ming, Zhou Zui, Chen Zhen, Zhao Hua, Lou Huan, Zhai Jing, Su Li, Yue Yi and their fellows who implemented their intentions; Wu Qi, Sun Bin, Dai Tuo, Ni Liang, Wang Liao, Tian Ji, Lian Po, Zhao She and their comrades who commanded their troops.

sentences.zh: 常以十倍之地，百萬之眾，叩關而攻秦。

translations.text: Constantly with ten times the territory and millions of masses, they knocked on the passes and attacked Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦人開關延敵，九國之師逡巡遁逃而不敢進。

translations.text: The Qin people opened their passes and drew in the enemy; the armies of the Nine States hesitated, retreated, and fled without daring to advance.

sentences.zh: 秦無亡矢遺鏃之費，而天下諸侯已困矣。

translations.text: Qin, without the expense of a lost arrow or arrowhead, had already exhausted all the feudal lords under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 於是從散約解，爭割地而奉秦。

translations.text: Thereupon the vertical alliance scattered and the agreements dissolved; they competed with each other to cede territory and pay tribute to Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦有餘力而制其敝，追亡逐北，伏尸百萬，流血漂鹵。

translations.text: Qin had surplus strength and exploited their exhaustion, pursuing the fleeing and chasing the retreating; corpses lay by the million and flowing blood floated shields.

sentences.zh: 因利乘便，宰割天下，分裂河山，彊國請服，弱國入朝。

translations.text: Taking advantage and seizing the opportunity, they carved up all under Heaven and divided its mountains and rivers; strong states requested to submit, weak states came to pay court.

sentences.zh: 延及孝文王、莊襄王，享國日淺，國家無事。

translations.text: Extending to King Xiaowen and King Zhuangxiang, they ruled only briefly and the state had no major affairs.

sentences.zh: 及至秦王，續六世之餘烈，振長策而御宇內，吞二周而亡諸侯，履至尊而制六合，執棰拊以鞭笞天下，威振四海。

translations.text: When it came to the King of Qin, he continued the remaining achievements of six generations, wielding long-term strategies to control the realm; he swallowed the Two Zhous and destroyed the feudal lords, trod upon the supreme position and mastered the six directions, grasped the whip to flog all under Heaven, and his awesome power shook the four seas.

sentences.zh: 南取百越之地，以為桂林、象郡，百越之君俛首系頸，委命下吏。

translations.text: He took south the lands ofhundred Yue, making them Guilin and Xiang commanderies; the lords ofhundred Yuebowed their heads and bound their necks,entrusted their livesto subordinate officials.

sentences.zh: 乃使蒙恬北筑長城而守藩籬，卻匈奴七百餘里，胡人不敢南下而牧馬，士不敢彎弓而報怨。

translations.text: He then sent Meng Tian north to build the Great Wall and guard the frontier defenses, driving back the Xiongnu over seven hundred li; the Hu people dared not venture south to pasture their horses, and their warriors dared not draw their bows to avenge their grievances.

sentences.zh: 於是廢先王之道，焚百家之言，以愚黔首。

translations.text: Thereupon he abolished the former kings' Way and burned the words of the hundred schools to make the black-headed people foolish.

sentences.zh: 墮名城，殺豪俊，收天下之兵聚之咸陽，銷鋒鑄鐻，以為金人十二，以弱黔首之民。

translations.text: He razed famous cities, killed heroes and worthy men, collected all under Heaven's weapons and gathered them at Xianyang, melted down sharp blades and cast bells, to make twelve metal men and weaken the black-headed people.

sentences.zh: 然後斬華為城，因河為津，據億丈之城，臨不測之谿以為固。

translations.text: Then he cut through Mount Hua as walls, relied on the river as a ford, occupied billion-zhang high walls, and overlooked unfathomable valleys to create a defense.

sentences.zh: 良將勁弩守要害之處，信臣精卒陳利兵而誰何，天下以定。

translations.text: Excellent generals and powerful crossbows guarded strategic points; trusted officials and elite troops arrayed sharp weapons and challenged whoever came; all under Heaven was settled.

sentences.zh: 秦王之心，自以為關中之固，金城千里，子孫帝王萬世之業也。

translations.text: In the Qin king's mind, he considered that Guanzhong's defenses, its golden walls of a thousand li, were a ten-thousand-generation enterprise for his descendants to rule as emperors.

In the Qin king's mind, he considered that Guanzhong's defenses, its golden walls of a thousand li, were a ten-thousand-generation enterprise for his descendants to rule as emperors.

sentences.zh: 秦王既沒，餘威振於殊俗。

translations.text: After the Qin king died, his remaining awesome power still shook foreign lands.

sentences.zh: 陳涉，罋牖繩樞之子，甿隸之人，而遷徙之徒，才能不及中人，非有仲尼、墨翟之賢，陶朱、猗頓之富，躡足行伍之閒，而倔起什伯之中，率罷散之卒，將數百之眾，而轉攻秦。

translations.text: Chen She was the son of a broken jar for a window and rope for a hinge, a person of lowly farming stock, and a vagrant; his talents did not reach those of an average person, he did not have the worthiness of Zhongni or Mo Di, nor the wealth of Tao Zhu or Yi Dun; stepping among the ranks, yet suddenly rising among squad and platoon leaders, he led weary and scattered soldiers, commanded several hundred men, and turned to attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 斬木為兵，揭竿為旗，天下雲集響應，贏糧而景從，山東豪俊遂并起而亡秦族矣。

translations.text: Cutting wood as weapons, raising poles as flags, all under Heaven gathered like clouds and responded, winning provisions and following like shadows; Shandong heroes and worthy men thereupon rose together and destroyed the Qin clan.

After the Qin king died, his remaining awesome power still shook foreign lands. Chen She was the son of a broken jar for a window and rope for a hinge, a person of lowly farming stock, and a vagrant; his talents did not reach those of an average person, he did not have the worthiness of Zhongni or Mo Di, nor the wealth of Tao Zhu or Yi Dun; stepping among the ranks, yet suddenly rising among squad and platoon leaders, he led weary and scattered soldiers, commanded several hundred men, and turned to attack Qin. Cutting wood as weapons, raising poles as flags, all under Heaven gathered like clouds and responded, winning provisions and following like shadows; Shandong heroes and worthy men thereupon rose together and destroyed the Qin clan.

sentences.zh: 且夫天下非小弱也，雍州之地，殽函之固自若也。

translations.text: Moreover, all under Heaven was not small or weak; Yongzhou's territory and Xiao and Han's defenses remained as before.

sentences.zh: 陳涉之位，非尊於齊、楚、燕、趙、韓、魏、宋、衛、中山之君；

translations.text: Chen She's position was not more honored than the lords of Qi, Chu, Yan, Zhao, Han, Wei, Song, Wei, and Zhongshan;

sentences.zh: 鉏櫌棘矜，非錟於句戟長鎩也；

translations.text: Hoes, rakes, and thorny clubs were not sharper than hooked halberds and long dagger-axes;

sentences.zh: 適戍之眾，非抗於九國之師；

translations.text: The garrison conscripts could not match the armies of the Nine States;

sentences.zh: 深謀遠慮，行軍用兵之道，非及鄉時之士也。

translations.text: Deep far-reaching plans and the way of military campaigns did not equal those of the men of former times.

sentences.zh: 然而成敗異變，功業相反也。

translations.text: Yet success and failure differed, and achievements and enterprises were contrary.

sentences.zh: 試使山東之國與陳涉度長絜大，比權量力，則不可同年而語矣。

translations.text: If you try to have the Shandong states and Chen She measure length and compare size, compare and weigh power, then they cannot be spoken of in the same terms.

sentences.zh: 然秦以區區之地，千乘之權，招八州而朝同列，百有餘年矣。

translations.text: Yet Qin with its small territory, a thousand chariots' authority, attracted the eight provinces and held court with peers for over a hundred years.

sentences.zh: 然後以六合為家，殽函為宮，一夫作難而七廟墮，身死人手，為天下笑者，何也？

translations.text: Then to make the six directions as home, Xiao and Han as palace; one man caused trouble and the seven temples collapsed, his body died at men's hands, becoming the laughingstock of all under Heaven—why?

sentences.zh: 仁義不施而攻守之勢異也。

translations.text: Because benevolence and righteousness were not implemented and the strategic situations of attacking and defending differ.

Moreover, all under Heaven was not small or weak; Yongzhou's territory and Xiao and Han's defenses remained as before. Chen She's position was not more honored than the lords of Qi, Chu, Yan, Zhao, Han, Wei, Song, Wei, and Zhongshan; Hoes, rakes, and thorny clubs were not sharper than hooked halberds and long dagger-axes; The garrison conscripts could not match the armies of the Nine States; Deep far-reaching plans and the way of military campaigns did not equal those of the men of former times. Yet success and failure differed, and achievements and enterprises were contrary. If you try to have the Shandong states and Chen She measure length and compare size, compare and weigh power, then they cannot be spoken of in the same terms. Yet Qin with its small territory, a thousand chariots' authority, attracted the eight provinces and held court with peers for over a hundred years. Then to make the six directions as home, Xiao and Han as palace; one man caused trouble and the seven temples collapsed, his body died at men's hands, becoming the laughingstock of all under Heaven—why? Because benevolence and righteousness were not implemented and the strategic situations of attacking and defending differ.

sentences.zh: 秦并海內，兼諸侯，南面稱帝，以養四海，天下之士斐然鄉風，若是者何也？

translations.text: When Qin unified all within the seas, annexed the feudal lords, faced south and called himself emperor to rule the four seas, all under Heaven's scholars in admiration turned toward him—why was this so?

sentences.zh: 曰：近古之無王者久矣。

translations.text: It is said: In recent antiquity there had been no king for a long time.

sentences.zh: 周室卑微，五霸既歿，令不行於天下，是以諸侯力政，彊侵弱，眾暴寡，兵革不休，士民罷敝。

translations.text: The Zhou royal house was lowly, the Five Hegemons had already died, and commands were not implemented throughout the land; therefore feudal lords ruled by force, the strong invaded the weak, the many oppressed the few, weapons and war did not cease, and warriors and people were exhausted.

sentences.zh: 今秦南面而王天下，是上有天子也。

translations.text: Now Qin faced south and ruled all under Heaven; above there was a Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 既元元之民冀得安其性命，莫不虛心而仰上，當此之時，守威定功，安危之本在於此矣。

translations.text: The common people hoped to secure their lives; none did not with empty hearts look up to their superior; at this time, guarding awesome power and establishing achievements, the root of safety and danger was here.

When Qin unified all within the seas, annexed the feudal lords, faced south and called himself emperor to rule the four seas, all under Heaven's scholars in admiration turned toward him—why was this so? It is said: In recent antiquity there had been no king for a long time. The Zhou royal house was lowly, the Five Hegemons had already died, and commands were not implemented throughout the land; therefore feudal lords ruled by force, the strong invaded the weak, the many oppressed the few, weapons and war did not cease, and warriors and people were exhausted. Now Qin faced south and ruled all under Heaven; above there was a Son of Heaven. The common people hoped to secure their lives; none did not with empty hearts look up to their superior; at this time, guarding awesome power and establishing achievements, the root of safety and danger was here.

sentences.zh: 秦王懷貪鄙之心，行自奮之智，不信功臣，不親士民，廢王道，立私權，禁文書而酷刑法，先詐力而後仁義，以暴虐為天下始。

translations.text: The Qin king harbored greedy and base intentions, practiced self-reliant cleverness, did not trust meritorious officials, was not close to officials and people, abolished the kingly way, established personal authority, prohibited writings and imposed harsh punishments and laws, prioritized deception and force while placing last benevolence and righteousness, using cruel tyranny as the foundation for all under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 夫并兼者高詐力，安定者貴順權，此言取與守不同術也。

translations.text: Those who unify and annex honor deception and force; those who stabilize and tranquilize value following proper authority; this means that taking and holding require different techniques.

sentences.zh: 秦離戰國而王天下，其道不易，其政不改，是其所以取之守之者［無］異也。

translations.text: Qin emerged from the Warring States and ruled all under Heaven; its way did not change, its government did not reform; thus the means by which it took and held were not different.

sentences.zh: 孤獨而有之，故其亡可立而待。

translations.text: Alone possessing it, therefore its destruction could be immediate.

sentences.zh: 借使秦王計上世之事，并殷周之跡，以制御其政，後雖有淫驕之主而未有傾危之患也。

translations.text: If the Qin king had considered the affairs of earlier generations, combined the precedents of Yin and Zhou to regulate its government, later even if there were a licentious and arrogant ruler, there would not have been the danger of collapse.

sentences.zh: 故三王之建天下，名號顯美，功業長久。

translations.text: Therefore the Three Kings in establishing all under Heaven had illustrious titles and names, and long-lasting achievements and enterprises.

The Qin king harbored greedy and base intentions, practiced self-reliant cleverness, did not trust meritorious officials, was not close to officials and people, abolished the kingly way, established personal authority, prohibited writings and imposed harsh punishments and laws, prioritized deception and force while placing last benevolence and righteousness, using cruel tyranny as the foundation for all under Heaven. Those who unify and annex honor deception and force; those who stabilize and tranquilize value following proper authority; this means that taking and holding require different techniques. Qin emerged from the Warring States and ruled all under Heaven; its way did not change, its government did not reform; thus the means by which it took and held were not different. Alone possessing it, therefore its destruction could be immediate. If the Qin king had considered the affairs of earlier generations, combined the precedents of Yin and Zhou to regulate its government, later even if there were a licentious and arrogant ruler, there would not have been the danger of collapse. Therefore the Three Kings in establishing all under Heaven had illustrious titles and names, and long-lasting achievements and enterprises.

sentences.zh: 今秦二世立，天下莫不引領而觀其政。

translations.text: When the Qin Second Emperor was established, all under Heaven without exception craned their necks to observe his government.

sentences.zh: 夫寒者利裋褐而饑者甘糟糠，天下之嗷嗷，新主之資也。

translations.text: Those who are cold find short coarse robes beneficial, while those who are hungry find husks and dregs sweet; all under Heaven's clamoring was the new lord's resource.

sentences.zh: 此言勞民之易為仁也。

translations.text: This means that with laboring people it is easy to practice benevolence.

sentences.zh: 鄉使二世有庸主之行，而任忠賢，臣主一心而憂海內之患，縞素而正先帝之過，裂地分民以封功臣之後，建國立君以禮天下，虛囹圉而免刑戮，除去收帑汙穢之罪，使各反其鄉里，發倉廩，散財幣，以振孤獨窮困之士，輕賦少事，以佐百姓之急，約法省刑以持其後，使天下之人皆得自新，更節修行，各慎其身，塞萬民之望，而以威德與天下，天下集矣。

translations.text: If the Second Emperor had had the conduct of a mediocre ruler and employed loyal and worthy men, if lord and ministers had been united in purpose while worrying about troubles within the seas, worn white mourning garments to rectify the First Emperor's errors, divided territory and people to enfeoff descendants of meritorious officials, established states and installed lords to show respect to all under Heaven, emptied prisons and pardoned those sentenced to punishments, removed and canceled charges for confiscated property and corruption, made each return to their villages, opened granaries, distributed wealth to relieve the lonely, poor, and distressed, lightened taxes and reduced corvée to aid the people's urgent needs, simplified laws and reduced punishments to maintain the future, enabled all under Heaven's people to obtain self-renewal, again moderate their conduct, each be careful with themselves, fulfill the people's hopes, and with awesome virtue shared all under Heaven, all under Heaven would have gathered.

sentences.zh: 即四海之內，皆讙各自安樂其處，唯恐有變，雖有狡猾之民，無離上之心，則不軌之臣無以飾其智，而暴亂之姦止矣。

translations.text: If all within the four seas would rejoice, each content in their positions, only fearing change, even if there were cunning people without hearts departing from their superior, then treacherous ministers would have no way to display their cleverness, and violent rebellious treachery would cease.

sentences.zh: 二世不行此術，而重之以無道，壞宗廟與民，更始作阿房宮，繁刑嚴誅，吏治刻深，賞罰不當，賦斂無度，天下多事，吏弗能紀，百姓困窮而主弗收恤。

translations.text: The Second Emperor did not follow this technique, but compounded it with lacking the Way, destroyed ancestral temples and the people, again began building Epang Palace, multiplied punishments and harsh executions, officials' administration was harsh and severe, rewards and punishments were inappropriate, taxation was without limit, all under Heaven was in much turmoil, officials could not record it all, the hundred clans were impoverished and distressed while the lord did not care for them.

sentences.zh: 然後姦偽并起，而上下相遁，蒙罪者眾，刑戮相望於道，而天下苦之。

translations.text: Then treachery and fraud arose together, and superiors and inferiors mutually evaded responsibility; those who suffered punishment were numerous, executions and punishments lined the roads, and all under Heaven suffered from it.

sentences.zh: 自君卿以下至于眾庶，人懷自危之心，親處窮苦之實，咸不安其位，故易動也。

translations.text: From lord and duke downward to the common masses, people harbored fears for their own safety, personally dwelt in actual poverty and suffering, all insecure in their positions, and therefore easily moved to rebellion.

sentences.zh: 是以陳涉不用湯武之賢，不藉公侯之尊，奮臂於大澤而天下響應者，其民危也。

translations.text: Therefore Chen She did not possess the worthiness of Tang and Wu, did not rely on the honor of dukes and marquises, raised his arm at Daze and all under Heaven responded, because the people were in danger.

sentences.zh: 故先王見始終之變，知存亡之機，是以牧民之道，務在安之而已。

translations.text: Therefore the former kings saw the changes of beginning and end and understood the key to survival and destruction; therefore the way of shepherding the people is that the priority is simply in making them secure.

sentences.zh: 天下雖有逆行之臣，必無響應之助矣。

translations.text: Though all under Heaven has rebellious ministers, there will surely be no responsive assistance.

sentences.zh: 故曰「安民可與行義，而危民易與為非」，此之謂也。

translations.text: Therefore it is said 'with secure people one can practice righteousness, while with endangered people it is easy to do wrong'—this is what it means.

sentences.zh: 貴為天子，富有天下，身不免於戮殺者，正傾非也。

translations.text: Noble as Son of Heaven, wealthy possessing all under Heaven, yet the body did not avoid execution—because the government was warped and wrong.

sentences.zh: 是二世之過也。

translations.text: This was the Second Emperor's fault.

When the Qin Second Emperor was established, all under Heaven without exception craned their necks to observe his government. Those who are cold find short coarse robes beneficial, while those who are hungry find husks and dregs sweet; all under Heaven's clamoring was the new lord's resource. This means that with laboring people it is easy to practice benevolence. If the Second Emperor had had the conduct of a mediocre ruler and employed loyal and worthy men, if lord and ministers had been united in purpose while worrying about troubles within the seas, worn white mourning garments to rectify the First Emperor's errors, divided territory and people to enfeoff descendants of meritorious officials, established states and installed lords to show respect to all under Heaven, emptied prisons and pardoned those sentenced to punishments, removed and canceled charges for confiscated property and corruption, made each return to their villages, opened granaries, distributed wealth to relieve the lonely, poor, and distressed, lightened taxes and reduced corvée to aid the people's urgent needs, simplified laws and reduced punishments to maintain the future, enabled all under Heaven's people to obtain self-renewal, again moderate their conduct, each be careful with themselves, fulfill the people's hopes, and with awesome virtue shared all under Heaven, all under Heaven would have gathered. If all within the four seas would rejoice, each content in their positions, only fearing change, even if there were cunning people without hearts departing from their superior, then treacherous ministers would have no way to display their cleverness, and violent rebellious treachery would cease. The Second Emperor did not follow this technique, but compounded it with lacking the Way, destroyed ancestral temples and the people, again began building Epang Palace, multiplied punishments and harsh executions, officials' administration was harsh and severe, rewards and punishments were inappropriate, taxation was without limit, all under Heaven was in much turmoil, officials could not record it all, the hundred clans were impoverished and distressed while the lord did not care for them. Then treachery and fraud arose together, and superiors and inferiors mutually evaded responsibility; those who suffered punishment were numerous, executions and punishments lined the roads, and all under Heaven suffered from it. From lord and duke downward to the common masses, people harbored fears for their own safety, personally dwelt in actual poverty and suffering, all insecure in their positions, and therefore easily moved to rebellion. Therefore Chen She did not possess the worthiness of Tang and Wu, did not rely on the honor of dukes and marquises, raised his arm at Daze and all under Heaven responded, because the people were in danger. Therefore the former kings saw the changes of beginning and end and understood the key to survival and destruction; therefore the way of shepherding the people is that the priority is simply in making them secure. Though all under Heaven has rebellious ministers, there will surely be no responsive assistance. Therefore it is said 'with secure people one can practice righteousness, while with endangered people it is easy to do wrong'—this is what it means. Noble as Son of Heaven, wealthy possessing all under Heaven, yet the body did not avoid execution—because the government was warped and wrong. This was the Second Emperor's fault.
